Assumes the full repayment of all amounts outstanding under the Bridge Credit Facilities and the termination of all available borrowings thereunder with proceeds from the offering of the notes. (4) Reflects an exchange rate from US$ to sterling of 1.36. (5) Reflects the equity purchase consideration in connection with the G4S Acquisition of $5,207 million and costs related to the G4S Refinancing of $3,096 million, including the repayment of accrued and unpaid interest on the Existing G4S Debt and associated make-whole redemption and change of control costs. We expect that approximately $2,746 million of the Existing G4S Debt will remain outstanding on the issue date of the notes offered hereby, with all such indebtedness expected to be repaid within approximately 150 days ----- following the issue date of the notes offered hereby. However, certain of the Existing G4S Debt may not be capable of voluntary prepayment on its terms, except in connection with certain adverse changes in taxation and as a result such repayment would be subject to the implementation of a tender offer in respect of such Existing G4S Debt and/or certain amendments to the instruments governing such Existing G4S Debt. See “— Recent Developments—The Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds.” -----

As of and for the year ended December 31, 2020, G4S entities organized in the United States, Luxembourg and England and Wales represented approximately 49.0% of G4S’s total revenues and 61.0% of G4S’s total assets. -----
Our major equity investors include the following:

Warburg Pincus LLC is a leading global private equity firm focused on growth investing. The firm has more than $58 billion in private equity assets under management. The firm’s active portfolio of more than 190 companies is highly diversified by stage, sector and geography. Warburg Pincus is an experienced partner to management teams seeking to build durable companies with sustainable value. Founded in 1966, Warburg Pincus has raised 19 private equity funds, which have invested more than $81 billion in over 890 companies in more than 40 countries. The firm is headquartered in New York with offices in Amsterdam, Beijing, Berlin, Hong Kong, Houston, London, Luxembourg, Mumbai, Mauritius, San Francisco, São Paulo, Shanghai and Singapore.

_This summary highlights information appearing elsewhere in this offering circular. This summary is not complete and does not contain all of the information that you should consider before investing in the notes. You should carefully read this entire offering circular, including our financial statements and related notes contained in this offering circular and the sections entitled “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.” Unless the context otherwise requires, references in this offering circular to “Allied Universal,” the “Company,” “we,” “us” and “our” refer to Allied Universal Holdco LLC and its consolidated subsidiaries. The term “Allied issuer” refers to Allied Universal Holdco LLC and not to any of its subsidiaries. The term “LuxCo co-issuer” refers to Atlas LuxCo 4 S.à r.l. and not to any of its subsidiaries. The term “Allied co-issuer” refers to Allied Universal Finance Corporation and not to any of its subsidiaries. The term “issuers” collectively refers to the Allied issuer, the LuxCo co-issuer and the Allied co-issuer and not to any of their subsidiaries._

Founded in 1996, Partners Group is a global private markets investment management firm with $95 billion in assets under management in private equity, private real estate, private infrastructure and private debt. The firm manages a broad range of customized portfolios for an international clientele of institutional investors. Partners Group is headquartered in Zug, Switzerland and has offices in Denver, Houston, Toronto, New York, São Paulo, London, Guernsey, Paris, Luxembourg, Milan, Munich, Dubai, Mumbai, Singapore, Manila, Shanghai, Seoul, Tokyo and Sydney. The firm employs over 1,500 people and is listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange (symbol: PGHN) with a major ownership by its partners and employees.

The J. Safra Group (“Safra” and, collectively with Warburg Pincus LLC, CDPQ and Partners Group, the “Investor Group”), with total assets under management of over $270 billion, is controlled by the Joseph Safra family. Safra consists of privately owned banks under the Safra name and investment holdings in asset-based business sectors such as real estate and agribusiness. Safra’s banking interests count over 160 locations globally and there are more than 35,000 employees associated with Safra. With deep relationships in markets worldwide, Safra is able to greatly enhance the value of businesses which are part of it.

Allied Universal Holdco LLC is a limited liability company organized under the laws of the State of Delaware in 2015. Allied Universal Finance Corporation is a corporation incorporated in Delaware in 2019. Our principal executive offices are located at 1551 North Tustin Avenue, Suite 650, Santa Ana, CA 92705. We also maintain a website at www.aus.com. **The information on, or accessible through, our website is not part of this offering

Subsubsection Text: CDPQ was created in 1965 and is one of Canada’s leading institutional asset managers and a mandatary of the Government of Québec. Pursuant to its constituting act, CDPQ’s mission is to receive moneys on deposit as provided by law and manage them with a view to achieving optimal return on capital within the framework of depositors’ investment policies while at the same time contributing to Québec’s economic development. As at December 31, 2019, CDPQ had 41 depositors primarily consisting of Québec public and parapublic pension and insurance plans. Depositors’ total and net assets were C$392.6 billion and C$340.1 billion, respectively, as at December 31, 2019. As one of Canada’s leading institutional fund managers, CDPQ invests globally in a wide range of asset classes, including major financial markets, private equity, infrastructure, real estate and private debt. In private equity, CDPQ has approximately C$50.2 billion in net assets under management and invests in a broad range of sectors worldwide, with a focus on Canada, the United States and Europe. It seeks to partner with and invest in unique companies, and focuses on helping to build and grow great businesses over the long term.

Ranking: Secured notes .............................................. The secured notes will be the issuers’ and the related guarantees will be the guarantors’ senior secured obligations and will: - rank equally in right of payment with all of the issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future senior indebtedness, including the unsecured notes, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes, the Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities; - be effectively senior to all of the issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future unsecured indebtedness, including the unsecured notes, the Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes and junior lien indebtedness to the extent of the value of the assets securing the secured notes and effectively junior to the ABL Credit Facility to the extent of the value of the ABL Collateral; - be pari passu with all of the issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future obligations secured on a first lien basis (other than the obligations secured on a first lien basis on the Excluded Assets and ABL Collateral); - be effectively junior to all of the issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future obligations secured on a first lien basis on the Excluded Assets or ABL Collateral, including obligations under the ABL Credit Facility to the extent of the value of such assets; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the issuers’ and each guarantor’s future subordinated indebtedness and other obligations that expressly provide for their subordination to the secured notes and the related guarantees; and - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness, claims of holders of preferred stock and other liabilities of any subsidiary of the issuers that are not guarantors of the secured notes. Unsecured notes .......................................... The unsecured notes will be the Allied issuer’s and the Allied co-issuer’s and the related guarantees will be the guarantors’ senior unsecured obligations and will: - rank equally in right of payment with all of the issuers’ and the guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness, ----- including the secured notes, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes, the Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future secured indebtedness of the issuers and the guarantors, including the secured notes, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, to the extent of the value of the assets securing such secured indebtedness; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the issuers’ and each guarantor’s future subordinated indebtedness and other obligations that expressly provide for their subordination to the unsecured notes and the related guarantees; and - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness, claims of holders of preferred stock and other liabilities of any subsidiary of the issuers that is not a guarantor of the unsecured notes. As of December 31, 2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, the issuers and the guarantors would have had $11,457.0 million in total indebtedness outstanding, none of which would have been subordinated and of which $9,120.0 million would have been senior secured indebtedness (in each case excluding capital lease obligations), consisting entirely of borrowings under the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities (after giving effect to the ABL Credit Facility Increase and excluding approximately $275.0 million of expected outstanding letters of credit under the ABL Credit Facility), the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and the secured notes. In addition, as of December 31, 2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, the issuers had an additional $300.0 million of availability to incur additional secured indebtedness under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, an additional €300.0 million of availability to incur additional secured indebtedness under the New Revolving Credit Facility and $1,500.0 million (subject to a borrowing base) of availability to incur additional secured indebtedness under the ABL Credit Facility (after giving effect to the ABL Credit Facility Increase and excluding approximately $275.0 million of expected outstanding letters of credit). Security: Secured Notes ............................................. The secured notes and related guarantees will be secured on a first lien basis by substantially all assets of the issuers and the guarantors (subject to certain agreed security principles and other than any Excluded Assets or ABL Collateral), which assets will also secure the issuers’ and the guarantors’ obligations under our Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, our New First Lien Term Loan Facilities and our New ----- Revolving Credit Facility ratably on a pari passu basis, subject to permitted liens. The secured notes and related guarantees will also be secured on a second-lien basis ratably on a pari passu basis with our Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, our New First Lien Term Loan Facilities and our New Revolving Credit Facility, subject to permitted liens, by the ABL Collateral that secures the ABL Credit Facility on a first lien basis. See “Description of Secured Notes—Security for the Sterling Secured Notes.” Unsecured Notes ......................................... The unsecured notes and the related guarantees will not be secured by any collateral. Intercreditor Agreements .................................. The relative rights in the Notes Collateral as between (a) the secured notes, (b) the Existing 2026 Secured Notes, (c) the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, (d) the New First Lien Term Loan Facilities and (e) the New Revolving Credit Facility will be set forth in the Pari Passu Intercreditor Agreement dated as of July 12, 2019 among Wilmington Trust, National Association, as the Initial Additional Collateral Agent (as defined therein), the Initial Additional Authorized Representative (as defined therein), and the other parties party thereto (the “Pari Passu Intercreditor Agreement”). The relative rights and priorities in the ABL Collateral as between (a) the secured notes, (b) the Existing 2026 Secured Notes, (c) the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, (d) the New First Lien Term Loan Facilities, (e) the New Revolving Credit Facility and (f) the ABL Credit Facility will be set forth in the ABL Intercreditor Agreement dated as of July 12, 2019 among Citibank, N.A., as ABL Representative (as defined therein), Wilmington Trust, National Association, as First Lien Notes Collateral Agent (as defined therein), and the other parties thereto (the “ABL Intercreditor Agreement” and, together with the Pari Passu Intercreditor Agreement, the “Intercreditor Agreements”). For a description of the Intercreditor Agreements, see “Description of Secured Notes—Security— ABL Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of Secured Notes—Security—Pari Passu Intercreditor Arrangements.” ----- Additional Amounts; Redemption for Taxation Reasons ............................ If payments made by any issuer or any guarantor on the sterling secured notes, USD secured notes tranche 2 and euro secured notes are subject to any withholding or deduction of taxes by certain relevant tax jurisdictions, subject to certain exceptions, the issuers and guarantors will be required to pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of Secured Notes—Additional Amounts.” In the event that certain changes in the tax law of any relevant jurisdiction would impose withholding taxes on payments on the notes and any additional amount is required as a result, the issuers may redeem the relevant note in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of Secured Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons” and “Description of Unsecured Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.” Optional redemption ......................................... At any time prior to      , 2024, the issuers, as applicable, may, at their option, redeem each series of notes, in whole or in part, at a redemption price equal to 100% of their principal amount plus a make-whole premium, together with accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon to, but excluding, the redemption date. From and after      , 2024, the issuers, as applicable, may, at their option, redeem each series of notes, in whole or in part, at the applicable redemption prices specified under “Description of Secured Notes—Optional Redemption” and “Description of Unsecured Notes—Optional Redemption,” together with accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon to, but excluding, the redemption date. In addition, at any time prior to      , 2024, the issuers, as applicable, may, at their option, redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of notes with an amount not to exceed the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the applicable redemption prices specified under “Description of Secured Notes—Optional Redemption” and “Description of Unsecured Notes—Optional Redemption,” together with accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon to, but excluding, the redemption date. In addition, on or before       , 2024, the issuers, as applicable, may redeem up to 10% of each series of the secured notes during each of the twelve-month periods ending after the issue date, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon to, but excluding, the redemption date. See “Description of Secured Notes—Optional Redemption” and “Description of Unsecured Notes—Optional Redemption.” ----- Change of control offer .................................... Upon the occurrence of specific kinds of changes of control, if we do not redeem the notes, you will have the right, as holders of the notes, to require the issuers to purchase some or all of your notes at 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon to, but excluding, the purchase date. See “Description of Secured Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of Unsecured Notes—Change of Control.” Certain covenants ............................................. Each series of notes will be issued under an indenture that will contain covenants that, among other things, limit the issuers’ ability and the ability of their restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue disqualified stock or certain preferred stock; - pay dividends and make other distributions or repurchase stock; - make certain investments; - create or incur liens; - sell assets; - enter into restrictions affecting the ability of restricted subsidiaries that are non-guarantors to make distributions, loans or advances or transfer assets to the issuers or the guarantors; - enter into certain transactions with the issuers’ affiliates; - designate restricted subsidiaries as unrestricted subsidiaries; and - merge, consolidate or transfer or sell all or substantially all of the issuers’ or the guarantors’ assets. These covenants are subject to a number of important limitations and exceptions. Most of these covenants will not apply to the issuers and their restricted subsidiaries during any period in which the applicable notes are rated investment grade by two of Fitch Ratings, Inc., Moody’s Investors Service, Inc. and Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services. See “Description of Secured Notes—Certain Covenants” and “Description of Unsecured Notes—Certain Covenants.” Transfer restrictions; no registration rights ...... The notes and the guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the Securities Act or any state securities laws. The notes are subject to restrictions on transfer and resale and may not be offered or sold except under an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the Securities Act and applicable state securities laws. We will not be required to complete a registered exchange offer or file a shelf registration statement ----- for resale of the notes. For more details, see “Transfer Restrictions.” No prior market ................................................ The notes will be new securities for which there is currently no market. Although the initial purchasers of the notes have advised us that they intend to make a market in the notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the notes. Listing .............................................................. Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of the non-USD notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the non-USD notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the non-USD notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended. We do not intend to apply for listing of the USD notes on any securities exchange or for inclusion of the USD notes in any automated dealer quotation system. Unsecured notes trustee .................................... The Bank of New York Mellon Trust Company, N.A. Registrar .......................................................... The Bank of New York Mellon Trust Company, N.A. We intend to use the net proceeds from this offering to (i) repay in full borrowings outstanding under the Bridge Credit Facilities and terminate all available borrowings thereunder and (ii) pay related fees, costs, premiums and expenses. Borrowings under the Bridge Credit Facilities and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, together with cash on hand and certain equity contributions, were used to (i) pay the acquisition consideration relating to the G4S Acquisition and (ii) pay related fees, costs, premiums and expenses in connection therewith. Subsubsection Text: Allied Adjusted EBITDA[(1)] ....................................................................... $ 938,322 $ 755,193 Pro Forma combined Adjusted EBITDA[(1)] ................................................ $1,955,925 Cash on a pro forma basis[(2)] ....................................................................... 812,229 Pro forma combined net secured debt[(2)] ..................................................... 8,307,771 Pro forma combined net total debt[(2)] .......................................................... 10,734,771 Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenue[(3)] ............................................... 18,357,142 Ratio of pro forma combined net secured debt to Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA[(1)] ............................................................................. 4.2x Ratio of pro forma combined net total debt to Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA[(1)] ............................................................................. 5.5x (1) We define Allied Adjusted EBITDA as net income (loss) before interest expense, net, income tax (benefit) expense and depreciation and amortization, as further adjusted to exclude certain non-cash items and certain cash expenses management considers non-recurring, unusual or otherwise not indicative of our ongoing operating performance and to reflect the full expected effect of cost reduction and profit-enhancing initiatives, acquisitions, disposals and related cost and revenue synergies. Specific adjustments for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 include adjustments for transaction, integration and restructuring costs, sponsor and director fees, non-cash equity-based compensation, legal settlements and related fees, certain adjustments related to the implementation of Allied Universal’s accounting standards, loss on disposal of property and equipment, loss on early extinguishment of debt, (gain) loss on disposal of businesses, and miscellaneous other non-recurring adjustments, as further adjusted to give effect to start-up costs and lease costs, profitimprovement initiatives, unrealized synergies from certain acquired businesses, management’s estimates of EBITDA from certain acquired businesses generated prior to their acquisition date, management’s estimates of EBITDA from certain businesses acquired in 2021, profits related to disposed businesses, and other nonrecurring adjustments, which are described in further detail below. Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA has been determined based on the combined statements of operations of Allied Universal and G4S for the year ended December 31, 2020 as adjusted as described under ”Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information,” and as further adjusted to reflect certain non-recurring adjustments and unrealized synergies in connection with the Financing Transactions and G4S Acquisition as described in further detail below. We define Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenue as Allied Universal’s historical revenue, as adjusted to give effect to businesses acquired during 2020 and 2021 by Allied Universal, plus G4S’s ----- historical revenue, as adjusted to give effect to revenue from businesses held for sale by G4S, onerous contracts, revenue from businesses disposed of by G4S during 2020 and 2021 and constant currency exchange rate adjustments. You are encouraged to evaluate these adjustments and the reasons we consider them appropriate for supplemental analysis. In evaluating these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures, you should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses that are the same as or similar to some of the adjustments in this presentation. Our presentation of these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items. We present these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures because we believe they assist management and investors when analyzing our performance by providing meaningful information that facilitates the comparability of underlying business results from period to period. We recognize these measures are not measurements of financial performance under GAAP and IFRS and there are limitations associated with the use of non-GAAP and non-IFRS financial measures. Some of these limitations are: - other companies may use different methods to calculate similar non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures, and the measures we present may not be directly comparable with the measures presented by these other companies as a result; - such measures do not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - such measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - such measures do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest payments, on our debts; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; - non-cash compensation is and will remain a key element of our overall long-term incentive compensation package, although we exclude it as an expense when evaluating our ongoing operating performance for a particular period; - such measures do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Allied Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA are adjusted to reflect certain acquisitions and certain unrealized acquisition synergies anticipated to be achieved in connection therewith. We present these adjustments as they will be permitted as adjustments to “EBITDA” under the indentures that will govern the notes offered hereby, although the non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures included herein may be defined differently than the corresponding terms under such indentures, and to enable investors to understand the covenants that will apply to us, and not as a projection of future results. We will be required to make cash expenditures to achieve such cost savings, and these cash costs are not reflected in Allied Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA. In addition, we will not fully realize such cost savings within 12 months of the completion of the Financing Transactions and the G4S Acquisition, and may not do so at all. Accordingly, you should not view our presentation of this adjustment as a projection that we will achieve these acquisition synergies. Our ability to realize these acquisition synergies is subject to significant uncertainties and you should not place undue reliance on the adjustments in evaluating our anticipated results. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industries—We may not realize the expected benefits, revenue or cost synergies related to recently completed or future acquisitions” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the G4S Acquisition—We may fail to realize all of the anticipated benefits ----- of the G4S Acquisition or those benefits may take longer to realize than expected. We may also encounter significant difficulties in integrating the G4S business.” Because of these limitations, these non-GAAP and non-IFRS financial measures should not be considered in isolation or as substitutes for, or as superior to, the presentation of results determined in accordance with GAAP or IFRS, as applicable. (640) 4,033 (640) Allied Adjusted EBITDA ................................................................... $ 938,322 $ 755,193** — G4S Acquisition Synergies[(q)] ...................................................... 155,000 Currency adjustment[(r)] ................................................................ 48,311 Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA[(r)] .....................................** $1,955,925 (a) Represents transaction, integration and restructuring related costs primarily associated with professional service fees paid to third parties for pre-acquisition due diligence and post-acquisition integration services, including operational, information technology, financial and other support services, as well as costs from re-branding of uniforms, vehicles, facilities and other materials, employee retention and discretionary bonuses as well as severance payments, costs incurred to consolidate facilities, employee travel costs and other items attributable to the acquisitions. For the year ended December 31, 2020, this adjustment includes $14.6 million in transaction costs related to the G4S Acquisition, as well as other costs associated with tuck-in acquisitions completed during 2020 and the first quarter of 2021. For the year ended December 31, 2019, the figure reflects $84.7 million in transaction costs related to the investments by CDPQ in Allied Universal, completed on December 12, 2019, as well as other costs associated with the acquisition of SOS Security and other tuck-in acquisitions. The pro forma transaction, integration and restructuring costs also include $43.7 million in costs incurred by G4S during 2020 for bid defense related to offers received from Garda World ----- Security Corporation and Allied Universal in 2020, $74.5 million in costs incurred by G4S for its 2018-2020 restructuring program and other transaction costs as if the Financing Transaction and G4S Acquisition had occurred on January 1, 2020. (b) Represents $6.8 million and $5.6 million in fees incurred from our sponsors for services rendered for strategic planning, management control matters, external financing and other services in 2020 and 2019, respectively. Additionally, $1.7 million and $1.4 million in director fees were paid in 2020 and 2019, respectively. The pro forma sponsor and directors’ fees adjustment for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2020 includes $8.5 million in sponsor and director fees as reported by Allied Universal for 2020 and $3.8 million in director fees incurred by G4S in 2020. (c) Represents non-cash equity-based compensation expense. (d) Represents non-recurring charges related to the settlement of class action lawsuits in excess of our insurance coverage, in addition to third party fees in connection with such litigation matters. This includes $14.2 million and $10.9 million related to the settlement of class action suits for unpaid wages, overtime, meal breaks and other items, in 2020 and 2019, respectively. The pro forma figure includes the 2020 legal settlements and related fees of Allied Universal and $134.8 million of legal settlements and related fees incurred by G4S during 2020, of which $66.8 million relates to the Deferred Prosecution Agreement entered into with the UK’s Serious Fraud Office, which was announced on July 10, 2020. (e) Represents charges related to non-cash write offs of property and equipment. The pro forma figure includes $3.8 million in loss on disposal of fixed assets related to G4S in addition to the $4.3 million reported by Allied Universal for 2020. (f) Represents charges related to the refinancing of the Company’s debt facility in July 2019. In connection with the refinancing, the Company recognized a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $88.3 million, which includes the write-off of existing deferred financing fees that had a carrying value of $62.4 million, $17.7 million of un-accreted original issue discount and $8.2 million of fees paid to noteholders in connection with the notes redemption. (g) Represents a gain recognized by G4S during 2020 in relation to the sale of the majority of G4S’s conventional cash businesses to The Brink’s Company in February 2020. (h) Represents other miscellaneous non-recurring costs. In 2020, other miscellaneous costs includes COVID-related costs of $8.5 million, discretionary deal incentives of $7.8 million, deferred compensation and severances of $3.4 million, consulting fees paid to third-parties for non-recurring projects of $2.3 million and other costs. In 2019, these costs include unusual workers’ compensation premium adjustments of $7.7 million, deferred compensation and severances of $2.9 million, consulting fees paid to third-parties for non-recurring projects of $2.8 million, one-time software development costs of $2.7 million and other costs. The pro forma figure includes Allied Universal amounts as reported, $11.0 million in one-time costs incurred by G4S as a result of COVID-19, $2.6 million in Guaranteed Minimum Pension benefit equalization charges as required by UK law, and other non-recurring costs incurred by G4S, which are partially offset by $5.1 million in income from joint ventures. (i) Represents management’s estimate of start-up costs incurred to onboard and train security professionals at the commencement of a new job. Start-up costs include an estimate for employees’ time, recruitment, travel and other related costs. Start-up costs fluctuate based on win rates and new job characteristics (e.g., location, type of customer, service provider requirements, etc.). (j) Represents adjustments for the estimated amortization of assets leased under operating leases based on the new lease standard adopted by Allied Universal during 2021. Pro forma lease costs include estimated lease costs incurred by G4S to conform to Allied Universal’s accounting policies. Pro forma ----- depreciation expense for G4S was adjusted by an equal and offsetting amount as G4S had already adopted IFRS 16, the new lease accounting standard, and had previously recognized lease costs as depreciation expense. (k) Represents adjustments to reflect the estimated impact of our profit-improvement initiatives including both revenue and cost savings initiatives. Based on our current initiatives, we expect to realize cost savings related to employee medical insurance, telecommunications, background checks incurred in recruiting process, workers’ compensation and other operating costs which on a combined basis would have resulted in estimated cost savings of approximately $9.0 million and $17.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Additionally, adjustments include the estimated impact of our margin improvement plan initiatives for which actions have been taken to increase bill rates, reduce non-billable overtime, increase customer billbacks for costs incurred on customers’ behalves, reduce fleet, travel and other recurring costs, and enhance staffing alignment in an effort to improve margins, which would have led to increased profitability totaling $42.0 million and $25.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. (l) Represents adjustments to reflect the estimated impact of unrealized cost saving synergies related to acquired businesses. Leveraging our existing infrastructure, we expect to realize cost savings primarily related to the elimination of redundant overhead personnel, consolidation of facilities, and other synergies from leveraging our scale, including lower insurance premiums and per employee benefit costs. Acquired businesses and timing of run-rate effect periods for synergies include Securadyne, from January 1, 2019 to April 14, 2019, Midstate Security Company, LLC (“Midstate”), from January 1, 2019 to August 25, 2019, SOS Security, from January 1, 2019 to December 30, 2019, Advent Systems, Inc. (“Advent”), from January 1, 2019 to November 2, 2019, APG Security (“APG”), from January 1, 2019 to November 24, 2019, Phoenix Systems & Service, Inc. (“PSSI”), from January 1, 2020 to July 16, 2020, Summit Security Services, Inc. (“Summit”), from January 1, 2020 to August 30, 2020, Service Works Inc. (“Service Works”), from January 1, 2020 to August 30, 2020, and Safe Environment Business Solutions, Inc. (“SEB”), from January 1, 2020 to October 15, 2020. (m) Represents adjustments to include the impact of EBITDA, adjusted for unusual, out-of-period and certain other items, from acquired businesses generated prior to their acquisition date. Acquired businesses, and the related pre-acquisition adjustment period, for the fiscal year ended December 30, 2019 include (i) Securadyne, from January 1, 2019 to April 14, 2019, (ii) Point 2 Point, from January 1, 2019 to May 2, 2019, (iii) Cypress, from January 1, 2019 to June 20, 2019, (iv) Shetler, from January 1, 2019 to July 11, 2019, (v) Midstate, from January 1, 2019 to August 25, 2019, (vi) Advent, from January 1, 2019 to November 2, 2019, (vii) Vinson, from January 1, 2019 to November 14, 2019, (viii) APG, from January 1, 2019 to November 24, 2019, and (ix) SOS Security from January 1, 2019 to December 30, 2019. Pre-acquisition adjusted EBITDA related to the SOS Security Acquisition was $42.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Acquisition adjusted EBITDA related to the other completed acquisitions were a combined $10.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Acquired businesses, and the related pre-acquisition adjustment period, for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2020 include (i) PSSI, from January 1, 2020 to July 16, 2020, (ii) Service Works, from January 1, 2020 to August 30, 2020, (iii) Summit, from January 1, 2020 to August 30, 2020, (iv) Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport (“BWI”) contract assets, from January 1, 2020 to September 30, 2020, (v) SEB, from January 1, 2020 to October 15, 2020, and (vi) Platt Security, from January 1, 2020 to November 19, 2020. Acquisition adjusted EBITDA related to the completed acquisitions were a combined $8.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. (n) Represents adjustments to include the impact of EBITDA, adjusted for the realization of expected synergies, from acquired businesses in the first quarter of 2021. Acquired businesses includes SecurAmerica, acquired on January 16, 2021, and two other tuck in acquisitions completed during the first quarter of 2021. Acquisition adjusted EBITDA related to these completed acquisitions were a combined $55.9 million on a pro forma basis for the year ended December 31, 2020. ----- (o) Represents pro forma adjustments to remove EBITDA earned by G4S on the conventional cash business sold to The Brink’s Company in February 2020 and for businesses held for sale during 2020 but for which the sale was not yet final as of December 31, 2020. (p) Reflects other non-recurring adjustments allowed by the Company’s debt covenants for integration costs incurred by administrative and shared service personnel and other miscellaneous non-recurring items, offset by EBITDA for the non-controlling interests in Allied Universal’s janitorial business. (q) For the year ended December 31, 2020, represents expected synergies related to the G4S Acquisition developed during our quality of earnings and due diligence process, which represents approximately $124 million of synergies driven by overlapping functions in North America (including approximately $11 million for facilities expenses, $22 million for field operations headcount, $20 million for sales headcount, $28 million for corporate headcount, $28 million for non-headcount and $14 million for direct labor cost improvements) and approximately $31 million of synergies from global G4S corporate cost, including general and administrative expenses and expenses in functional support areas that support G4S’s status as a public listed company. The synergies represent approximately one-third of addressable cost structure. We expect that approximately 60% of these synergies will be realized within the next 12 months, including all global G4S corporate costs, with the remainder expected to be realized by the end of 2022. To achieve these synergies, we expect to incur one-time costs of approximately $250 million. Our ability to realize the expected synergies and benefits of the G4S Acquisition is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, many of which are outside of our control, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the G4S Acquisition—We may fail to realize all of the anticipated benefits of the G4S Acquisition or those benefits may take longer to realize than expected. We may also encounter significant difficulties in integrating the G4S business.” (r) The average exchange rate used for translation of the reconciliation for the G4S portion of the pro forma combined amounts is 1.36 GBP to USD, which reflects the exchange rate related to hedges that were entered into prior of the submission of the Allied Universal’s offer for G4S and results in G4S Adjusted EBITDA of $862.6 million. Utilizing the average exchange rate during 2020 of 1.284 GBP to USD would result in G4S Adjusted EBITDA of $814.4 million. (2) The Company defines pro forma net secured debt as secured debt outstanding (after giving effect to the ABL Credit Facility Increase and excluding approximately $275.0 million of expected outstanding letters of credit under the ABL Credit Facility and approximately $92.0 million of capital leases, in each case as of December 31, 2020) less cash on a pro forma basis for the notes issued hereby. The Company defines pro forma net total debt as total debt outstanding (after giving effect to the ABL Credit Facility Increase and excluding approximately $275.0 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding under the ABL Credit Facility as of December 31, 2020) less cash on a pro forma basis for the notes issued hereby. Cash on a pro forma basis represents $1,704 million of Pro Forma Combined Cash as determined under “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” plus approximately $71 million for short term investments/marketable securities of G4S, less approximately $497 million of overdrafts and liabilities to customers for G4S as of December 31, 2020, $372 million of cash associated with tuck-in acquisitions completed during the first quarter of 2021 and $93 million of other transaction costs, net of the impact of foreign currency adjustments. Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED AND PRO FORMA COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth Allied Universal’s summary historical consolidated and unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information for the periods and dates indicated. The summary historical consolidated statement of operations data for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 and balance sheet data as of December 31, 2020 and 2019 have been derived from Allied Universal’s audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering circular. The summary unaudited pro forma combined statements of operations data for the year ended December 31, 2020 reflect the G4S Acquisition and related financing transactions as described under “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information,” as if such transactions had occurred on January 1, 2020. The summary unaudited pro forma combined balance sheet data as of December 31, 2020 reflect the G4S Acquisition and related financing transactions as described under “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” as if such transactions had occurred on December 31, 2020. The summary unaudited pro forma combined statements of operations data were prepared to illustrate the estimated effects of the G4S Acquisition and related financing transactions as described under “Unaudited Pro forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” as if such transactions had occurred on January 1, 2020. For each of the periods presented, the pro forma financial information reflects the combination of historical financial information of Allied Universal and G4S, adjusted to give effect to a preliminary purchase price allocation as described under “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial information.” Furthermore, additional pro forma adjustments have also been reflected to address differences in reporting currencies, differences in bases of accounting and differences in the classification and presentation of certain financial information. See “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information.” The unaudited pro forma adjustments are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances. The summary unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our actual combined results of operations or combined financial condition would have been had the G4S Acquisition described under the section “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” actually occurred on the dates indicated, nor do they purport to project our consolidated results of operations or consolidated financial condition for any other period or as of any other date. All pro forma adjustments and their underlying assumptions are described more fully in the notes under the section entitled “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information.” The following historical consolidated and unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information is only a summary and should be read in conjunction with the section entitled “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our historical consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering circular, as well as the information included under the section entitled “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information.”

For the year ended December 31, 2019, this adjustment reflects restructuring and separation charges of £57 million, which include restructuring costs of £19 million incurred by G4S for its 2018-2020 restructuring program. For the ----- year ended December 31, 2020 includes £105 million of legal settlements and related fees incurred by G4S, of which £52 million relates to the Deferred Prosecution Agreement entered into with the UK’s Serious Fraud Office which was announced on July 10, 2020. (e) Represents a pro forma gain recognized by G4S during 2020 in relation to the sale of the majority of G4S’s conventional cash businesses to The Brink’s Company in February 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2019, other miscellaneous consists primarily of £5 million of share of profit after tax from joint ventures and other miscellaneous income partially offset by other miscellaneous costs. (i) Represents management’s estimate of start-up costs incurred to onboard and train security professionals at the commencement of a new job. Start-up costs include an estimate for employees’ time, recruitment, travel and other related costs. Start-up costs fluctuate based on win rates and new job characteristics (e.g., location, type of customer, service provider requirements, etc.). (j) Represents adjustments for the estimated amortization of assets leased under operating leases on a pro forma basis as if G4S had adopted the new U.S. GAAP lease standard. Adjustment is a reclassification from depreciation expense and has no impact on G4S Adjusted EBITDA. (k) Represents pro forma adjustments to remove profits earned by G4S on the conventional cash business sold to The Brink’s Company in February 2020 and for businesses held for sale during 2020 but which the sale was not yet final. (l) Represents adjustment to restate the financial data for the year ended December 31, 2019 using the average currency exchange rate applicable to the year ended December 31, 2020. (m) The average exchange rate used for translation of the reconciliation for the G4S Adjusted EBITDA is 1.36 GBP to USD, which reflects the exchange rate related to hedges that were entered into prior of the submission of Allied Universal’s Offer for G4S and results in G4S Adjusted EBITDA of $862.6 million for 2020 and $859.5 million for 2019. Utilizing the average exchange rate during 2020 of 1.284 GBP to USD would result in G4S Adjusted EBITDA of $814.4 million for 2020 and $811.6 million for 2019. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF G4S
Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth G4S’s summary historical consolidated financial information for the periods and dates indicated. The summary historical consolidated income statement for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 and balance sheet data as of December 31, 2020 and 2019 have been derived from G4S’s audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering circular. The following G4S summary historical consolidated financial information has been prepared in accordance with IFRS and has not been converted into GAAP, which is the accounting framework used by Allied Universal. The following historical consolidated financial information is only a summary and should be read in conjunction with G4S’s historical consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering circular.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industries The COVID-19 pandemic, its scope and duration and the uncertainty related thereto may adversely affect our business, results of operations, cash flows, liquidity and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: The Company continues to closely monitor developments related to the COVID-19 pandemic to assess any potential impact on its business. While the Company currently does not anticipate that the COVID-19 pandemic will have a material adverse impact on its business, as a result of the evolving and highly uncertain nature of the COVID19 pandemic, no assurance may be made regarding potential exposure or the indirect effects of the outbreak on the Company’s business, results of operations, cash flows, liquidity and financial condition. The COVID-19 pandemic may heighten the potential adverse effects of the other risks on our business, including, but not limited to, the likelihood of and impact from: - overall economic conditions, globally and in the United States, which have been and will likely continue to be adversely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and related shutdowns; - our ability to maintain sufficient key personnel due to employee illness, quarantine requirements, worker absences, enhancements to unemployment compensation benefits and other government relief programs, social-distancing, travel or other restrictions; - reduced availability and productivity of labor; - continued or expanded closures of our customers’ facilities; - our customers’ demand and ability to pay for our services, or attempts by our customers to defer payments owed to us; - our ability to obtain new customers, expand, or otherwise execute strategic plans; - our ability to comply with new legal or regulatory requirements enacted in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic; - legal actions, claims or proceedings related to the COVID-19 pandemic; and - the ability of third parties on which we rely, including our suppliers and business partners, to timely meet their obligations to us, or significant disruptions in their ability to do so. -----

Subsection Title: The industries in which we operate are intensely competitive and price-sensitive. If we cannot successfully compete with new or existing providers of products and services similar to ours or enhance our existing products and services, our results of operations and financial condition will be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: The industries in which we operate are intensely competitive. We directly compete with companies that are national and international in scope. Our competitors may expand their current product and service offerings more rapidly, including by bundling the products and services they offer, adapting to new or emerging technologies more quickly, taking advantage of acquisitions or devoting greater resources to the marketing and sale of their products and services than we do. We also compete with smaller local and regional companies that may have better knowledge of the local conditions in their regions, are better known locally and are better able to gain customers in their regions. There are relatively low barriers to entry in the industries in which we operate, and we have faced and expect to continue to face additional competition from new entrants. In addition, it has become more common for our customers to select service providers through competitive bid processes intended to procure quality services at lower prices. Some of our competitors may be willing to provide services at lower prices, accept a lower profit margin or expend more capital in order to obtain or retain business. We may not be able to retain customer accounts at historic levels in an increasingly competitive market or acquire new customer accounts and retain existing customer accounts on terms as favorable as those previously available, and if we are unable to do so our business, financial condition and results of operations will be adversely affected. Rapid technological advances, changing delivery models and evolving standards in computer hardware and software development and communications infrastructure, changing and increasingly sophisticated customer needs and frequent new product introductions and enhancements characterize the industries in which we compete. As digital advancement develops, we may also face increased competition from technology companies. If we are unable to develop new or sufficiently differentiated, high quality products and services, respond to trends in the market, enhance and improve our product and service offerings in a timely manner or at all or position and price our products and services to meet demand, we may have difficulty retaining existing customers or growing our customer base.

Subsection Title: As a contractor with national and local governments, public sector bodies and agencies and government regulated customers, we are subject to procurement rules and regulations, procurement delays and service criteria.
Subsubsection Text: As a contractor with governments, public sector bodies and agencies, and government-regulated customers, we must comply with specific procurement regulations and other requirements, which can change from time to time. We may also be subject to additional data protection and confidentiality requirements in relation to government contracts. These requirements, although customary when entering into contracts with public sector bodies, increase our bidding, performance and compliance costs. There is also a risk that procurement requirements or “eligibility to bid” criteria may change, which could affect our eligibility to bid for such contracts and increase the costs of bidding for, or complying with, such contracts. Failure to comply with or satisfy bid criteria, procurement rules and regulations, to meet service levels and performance obligations, or to meet data protection and confidentiality requirements, could result in reductions in the number or value of contracts to be awarded to us and in not being allowed to participate in future tenders with government, public sector and government regulated customers, or contract modifications or terminations. In addition, inaccurate billing or pricing may lead to fraud claims from governments. Our inability to contract with public sector bodies at all or for a period of time could negatively impact our reputation and ability to procure public sector work in the future. Public sector projects may also require relevant governmental or other approvals. Difficulties in obtaining such approvals may lead to projects being delayed before procurement has started, during the tender stage or during the period between being appointed as the preferred bidder and execution of final contracts. Delays in awarding public contracts may also arise from challenges to the award of the contracts by competitors. These matters are beyond our control and any resulting delays could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. -----

Subsection Title: Our business is susceptible to economic downturns.
Subsubsection Text: While we have a diversified customer base across multiple geographies, as well as a network of blue chip accounts, many customers are located in urban centers and major metropolitan areas. As a result, periods of economic downturn can increase our attrition rate among existing customers. In the small business segment, customers were particularly impacted by the economic downturn and sought to reduce their costs or were forced to close their businesses. Small business subscriptions are more directly correlated to economic conditions. A recession or period of economic uncertainty could lead to increases in our attrition rate and could reduce the inflow of new customers purchasing our services and products. In addition, a recession or economic downturn could result in increased defaults or bankruptcies by our customers, reducing the likelihood of collecting accounts receivable from such customers. Periods of economic downturn can also negatively impact our ability to sell new products and services. A decline in outsourcing by clients, a reversal of the trend towards globalization in large corporations, any deterioration of the current economic situation in the market segments in which we operate, or in the global economy as a whole, and major changes in market dynamics, including new technologies, government legislation or customer consolidation could have a negative impact on our revenues and increase our financing costs, circumstances that could have a material adverse effect on the business, financial condition and our results of operations.

Subsection Title: Our standard customer contracts for security officer services are short-term, and if we are unable to retain our existing security officer service contracts or obtain new security service contracts, our results of operations and financial condition will be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Our standard customer contracts for security officer services are short-term, and if we are unable to retain our existing security officer service contracts or obtain new security service contracts, our results of operations and financial condition will be adversely affected. Our standard customer contract has a one-year term but may be terminated by either our customer or us with 30 days’ advance notice. Many of our larger contracts are multi-year but also allow for cancellation by either party with 30 to 90 days’ advance notice. We serve certain of our customers under month-to-month extensions of these written contracts. If we are not able to maintain our existing security service contracts or obtain additional security service contracts, our business, financial condition and results of operations will be adversely affected.

Subsection Title: The nature of our business exposes us to significant risks related to legal proceedings, claims, governmental inquiries and investigations, and negative press and media investigations that could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The nature of our business exposes us to significant risks related to legal proceedings, claims, governmental inquiries and investigations, and negative press and media investigations. In particular, the services we provide, the customers and facilities we serve, our employees, and our interactions with members of the public result in our facing significant inherent business, economic and reputational risks. The success of our business depends to a large extent on our reputation and our ability to maintain good relationships with our customers. In recent years, both Allied and G4S have been involved in numerous incidents that have resulted in lost business, reductions in revenue, legal and regulatory proceedings, governmental inquiries and investigations, fines and penalties, negative publicity and constraints on both companies’ ability to raise capital. Given the nature of our ongoing business, there can be no assurances that similar or more significant events will not happen in the future. The following are among such incidents in recent years: In 2019, Norway’s Sovereign Wealth Fund banned all financial holdings in G4S on the basis that the group contributes to or is responsible for serious or systematic human rights violations, noting that G4S takes custody of employment passports in certain geographies and certain employees had to take large loans to pay employment referral fees. In 2019, G4S lost its contract to run Birmingham Prison as a result of operational failures. Among others, the British government alleged that the Birmingham facility had the highest assault rate of any prison in England and ----- Wales. In 2017, BBC’s Panorama program obtained undercover footage of detainees allegedly being abused at Brook House, an immigration center operated by G4S. As a result of G4S’ investigation and the BBC program, 14 of the 21 staff members allegedly involved either resigned or had their employment terminated. There have been (and continue to be) various public inquiries and investigations into these events. G4S did not seek to renew its contracts to run Gatwick’s immigration removal centers, including Brook House, which expired in May 2020. Further, in 2016, BBC’s Panorama program accused G4S staff of allegedly using unnecessary force and inappropriate language with teenage boys at the Medway Secure Training Centre, Rochester. Sixteen people were later arrested, however there were no convictions. G4S held the contract to run the Medway Secure Training Centre, Rochester, from 1998 to 2016, at which point G4S’s contract was not renewed. Claims have been brought on behalf of American service members alleging that G4S, as well as a number of other multinational companies operating in Afghanistan, including U.S. companies, provided support to the Taliban in Afghanistan. The claims have been brought under the U.S. Anti-Terrorism Act on behalf of American service members and civilians who were killed or injured in Afghanistan. There are approximately 900 plaintiffs as of April 2021. G4S’s motion to dismiss is currently pending and potential monetary damages, if any, are not yet known. G4S’s executives, managers and guards are alleged to have failed to secure weapons owned by G4S despite warnings that its missing weapons have been used in crimes. We believe that more than 600 G4S weapons have been reported lost or stolen since 2009. In 2016, a G4S employee who had passed G4S background checks despite being placed on a terror watch list committed a nightclub shooting in Orlando, Florida, which killed 49 people and injured another 53. Although the employee was off-duty and used his own weapon, the incident resulted in negative publicity. Florida’s Fourth District Court of Appeal upheld a 2018 trial court’s dismissal of a negligence lawsuit against G4S brought by survivors of relatives of the deceased. In 2013, the UK Serious Fraud Office (“SFO”) commenced a criminal investigation of G4S Care and Justice Services Limited (“G4S C&J”) based on allegations that it had been overcharging and providing fraudulent invoices and financial reporting to the Ministry of Justice for services related to electronic monitoring. In 2014, G4S C&J reported to the SFO that it had failed to provide accurate financial reports to the Ministry of Justice and later settled with the Ministry of Justice. The SFO then charged G4S C&J with three past offenses of fraud. In July 2020, G4S C&J entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the SFO, which is set to conclude in July 2023 and G4S plc made a binding undertaking to ensure compliance. In 2019, shareholders brought a class action claim seeking damages for alleged losses following G4S’s share price decline in 2013 as a result of omitting information about wrongful billing practices with respect to G4S’s contract with the UK government. Although G4S won a motion to strike 90% of the claimants from the case on procedural grounds, the judge is allowing these institutional investors to challenge his decision to bar most of them from suing G4S. The Belgian Competition Authority (BCA) and the Antitrust Division of the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) are conducting investigations into G4S’s Belgian business and allegations of price fixing with respect to government contracts. These investigations are ongoing. G4S is subject to a number of claims in India, mainly related to periods prior to 2011, regarding payments to the India Provident Fund (India’s retirement plan that is regulated on a state-by-state basis). The issue is whether G4S was correct to make payments based on basic wages, excluding other parts of the salary (such as bonuses), prior to 2011. In 2013, video footage from the Mangaung Correctional Centre showed alleged mistreatment of South African prisoners by G4S employees providing services there. G4S denied the allegations. In December 2013, South African government officials took over the maximum-security facility after G4S allegedly failed to effectively control the facility. Within ten months, G4S regained responsibility for servicing the prison from the government. In 2015, a group of South African prisoners sued G4S with respect to alleged mistreatment. G4S took over a contract with Israeli prisons in the West Bank after buying a competitor in 2002. International investors divested stakes in G4S amid accusations by international NGOs that G4S was complicit in war crimes. In 2015, G4S allowed certain Israeli contracts to expire. ----- Between October 2012 and March 2014, G4S Australia Pty. Ltd. operated the Manus Island Regional Centre in Papua, New Guinea, which was used to hold immigrants awaiting deportation. There were press reports of alleged human rights issues at such facility and a complaint by an international development organization, litigation brought by former employees and a class action brought by detainees relating to conditions at such facility. In March 2014, G4S Australia’s contract expired and it ceased its operation of the center and subsequently claims related to this matter were settled. Allied and G4S have taken significant steps to mitigate the consequences of all the above incidents. However, as set out above and in “Business—Legal Proceedings,” a number of these incidents are still subject to ongoing review, investigation and litigation. We can also make no assurances that similar, or more significant, incidents will not happen in the future. Such events in the past or future could result in negative publicity relating to the quality of our services or our brand, including as a result of a security incident or breach at one or more of our customers’ locations or shortfalls in our customer service. Such events could also result in damage to our reputation and the loss of existing or new customers legal proceedings, claims and governmental inquiries and investigations. Such incidents can accordingly have a negative effect on our revenues, exposure to significant litigation and regulatory risk, and result in overall reputational harm, all of which individually or in the aggregate can have and, in the past, had significant consequences for our business that could result in a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

Subsection Title: We are subject to increasing operating costs, including labor costs, and inflation risk which may adversely affect our earnings.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to increasing operating costs. We are also impacted by inflationary increases in salaries, wages, benefits and other administrative costs. Price increases are also associated with expenses, in particular, labor costs. As a result, our operating costs may increase faster than our associated revenues, resulting in a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Minimum wage legislation, complex labor legislation, shortages of qualified workers, termination benefits, payroll, payroll taxes and employee related benefits may also affect our ability to control labor costs. Specifically, we believe that we have higher wages and related payroll taxes and benefits costs than other participants in our industry due to our focus on attracting and retaining a highly qualified workforce. Furthermore, our payroll tax expenses historically are higher in the first half of the year because a significant number of employees do not reach their taxable wage limits for employer related federal and state unemployment taxes until the second half of the year. In the event that we experience a significant or material increase in labor costs and are not able to pass some or all of those costs on to our customers due to fixed hourly bill rates or fixed fee contracts, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Such fixed price contracts are primarily related to some of our government contracts. Because our business is labor intensive, we rely on being able to attract and retain high quality employees within all of the geographic regions and service areas in which we operate. On a combined basis after giving effect to the Transactions, we employ approximately 740,000 security professionals. Labor is a key component of the daily operation and continued growth of our business. While we believe that we have lower employee turnover than many of our competitors, turnover of contract security officers and administrative staff is significant in our industry, including at our Company. Any difficulties in attracting, training and retaining qualified personnel, including successors for departing personnel, may have an adverse impact on our results. A significant portion of our employees work under collective bargaining agreements. These existing collective bargaining agreements may not be able to be extended or renewed on their current terms, and we may be unable to negotiate collective bargaining agreements in a favorable and timely manner. We may also become subject to additional collective bargaining agreements in the future or our non-unionized workers may unionize, any of which may could have a material adverse effect on our costs, operations and business. -----

Subsection Title: Our success depends on our ability to attract and retain the members of our management team, key employees and other qualified personnel.
Subsubsection Text: Our success is dependent upon the continuing efforts, abilities and business generation capabilities of our management team and other key employees. We have programs in place to motivate, reward and retain our management teams and such key employees, including cash bonus and equity incentive plans. However, the loss or departure of members of our management team or other key employee could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations, and we may not be able to attract and retain individuals with the same or similar levels of experience or expertise. Additionally, screening and vetting of qualified personnel is a challenge in some territories, which lack supporting infrastructure from the relevant authorities. Factors, such as minimum levels of training and/or licenses for employees in certain positions in various countries and increasing levels of regulation, may limit our ability to recruit new employees and replace leaving employees effectively, thereby limiting our ability to expand our business. Any incident where our people fail to meet the expectations of our customers and other stakeholders, including the effective sourcing, supervising, training and screening of staff, or nonadherence by employees and contractors to our culture and values as designed and expected, could lead to significant reputational harm and material adverse effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Competition for qualified senior managers and other key employees in our industry is intense, and there is limited availability of persons with the relevant experience. We could experience a delay or higher costs in order to attract, train and retain qualified senior managers and such key employees from time to time.

Subsection Title: Our business operates in a regulated industry, and noncompliance with regulations could materially restrict our operations and expose us to fines, penalties and other liabilities and negative consequences.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations and employees are subject to various laws and regulations, including a large number of city, county, state and federal occupational licensing laws and regulations that apply to security officers. Relevant regulation for our operations and employees includes such matters as consumer protection, wage and hour rules (or “labor laws”), fair trade, jurisdiction-specific security industry regulation (including with respect to hardware requirements or operational requirements), data privacy, marketing and competition law. Additionally, most states in the United States have laws, or legislation pending, requiring qualification, training and registration of security officers, regulating the use of identification cards, badges and uniforms and imposing minimum bond surety or insurance standards. In order to install a security system, we generally must be licensed in the jurisdiction where we are installing the system. Additionally, we generally must obtain operating certificates or permits for our security systems, and provide specified levels of training to our employees at those centers. We are also governed by regulations relating to when we can forward alarms to emergency providers, and are subject to certain consequences if we forward false alarms to such emergency providers. Any failure to comply with the laws, rules or regulations (local or otherwise) in which we operate may result in fines, penalties or a suspension or termination of our right to provide our security services in the relevant jurisdiction. Additionally, changes in laws or regulations in the jurisdictions in which we operate could cause us to incur significant costs and expenses to comply with such laws or regulations, or become unable to operate in the security market segment within the localities in which such laws or regulations are implemented, or could impact our sales channels. Such changes may also result in delays in commencement or completion of services for our customers or the need to modify completed installations. Any limitation on our ability to operate our business due to legal or regulatory reasons could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, we are subject to applicable laws and regulations relating to economic and trade sanctions and bribery and corruption, the violation of which could have a material adverse effect on us. Our failure to comply with applicable economic and trade sanctions laws and regulations may expose us to reputational harm as well as significant penalties, including criminal fines, imprisonment, civil fines, disgorgement of profits, injunctions and debarment from government contracts, as well as other remedial measures. We have adopted an anti-corruption policy and we train selected employees on anti-bribery compliance. However, our current policies and procedures may not address the full scope of all possible corruption-related risks, or employees or other persons acting on our behalf might act in a manner contrary to our anti-corruption policies and procedures, potentially creating liability for us under one or more anti-bribery laws, including the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and UK Bribery Act. Any such violation, even if prohibited by our policies and procedures, could have material adverse effects on our financial condition or reputation. -----

Subsection Title: We could be adversely affected by violations of the FCPA and other applicable anti-bribery laws of various jurisdictions, export controls, and economic and trade sanctions, and any investigation, and the outcome of any investigation, by government agencies of possible violations by us, our employees, and our business partners of these laws and regulations could have a material adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: We operate a global business, including in parts of the world that have experienced elevated rates of governmental corruption and have direct or indirect interactions with officials and employees of government agencies or state-owned or affiliated entities, including state-owned entity customers and government contractors and as participants in a highly regulated industry. The U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, or the FCPA, and other applicable anti-bribery laws prohibit companies and their intermediaries from corruptly providing, offering, promising, or authorizing, directly or indirectly, anything of value to government officials, political parties, or political candidates for the purposes of obtaining or retaining business or securing any improper business advantage. Our business must be conducted in compliance with applicable export controls and economic and trade sanctions laws and regulations, such as those administered and enforced by the U.S. Department of Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (“OFAC”), the U.S. Department of State, the U.S. Department of Commerce, the United Nations Security Council and other relevant governmental authorities. The U.S. Departments of Justice, Commerce, State and Treasury, the SEC, and other federal agencies and authorities have a broad range of civil and criminal penalties they may seek to impose against corporations and individuals for violations of economic sanctions laws, export control laws, the FCPA, and other federal statutes and regulations, including those established by the OFAC. In addition, the U.K. Bribery Act of 2010, or the Bribery Act, prohibits both domestic and international bribery, as well as bribery across both private and public sectors. An organization that fails to prevent bribery by anyone associated with the organization can be charged under the Bribery Act unless the organization can establish the defense of having implemented adequate procedures to prevent bribery.
