We will not be required to comply with these requirements and therefore we may not have comparable procedures in place as compared to other public companies.

Subsection Title: The indentures that will govern the notes offered hereby will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act, and we are not, and we will not be, required to comply with the provisions of the Trust Indenture Act.
Subsubsection Text: The indentures that will govern the notes offered hereby will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act, and we are not, and we will not be, required to comply with the provisions of the Trust Indenture Act. Therefore, holders of the notes offered hereby will not be entitled to the benefit of the provisions and protection of the Trust Indenture Act except to the extent there are similar provisions in the indentures that will govern the notes offered hereby. -----

Subsection Title: The Investor Group controls us, and the Investor Group’s interests may conflict with ours or those of the other holders of the notes offered hereby.
Subsubsection Text: The Investor Group collectively indirectly owns, through its ownership in Topco, the majority of our limited liability company units. In addition, pursuant to the limited liability company agreement of Topco, the Investor Group controls Topco. As a result, the Investor Group has control over our decisions to enter into any corporate transaction and has the ability to prevent any transaction that requires the approval of the manager or equityholder of us or Topco, regardless of whether the holders of notes believe that any such transactions are in their own best interests. For example, the Investor Group could cause us to make acquisitions that increase the amount of our indebtedness, including secured indebtedness, or to sell assets, which may impair our ability to make payments under the notes offered hereby. In addition, to the extent permitted by the credit agreements that govern our Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the credit agreements that will govern our New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the indentures governing our Existing 2026 Secured Notes and Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes and the indentures that will govern the notes offered hereby, the Investor Group may cause us to pay dividends rather than make capital expenditures or otherwise use our funds for the benefit of our business. In addition, the Investor Group is in the business of making investments in companies and may, from time to time, acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with us. The Investor Group may vote in a manner so as to restrict us from expanding our business or entering into additional lines of business, which may be related to the current or future operations of these investments. Also, the Investor Group may pursue acquisitions that may be complementary with our business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be available to us. So long as the Investor Group continues to indirectly own a significant amount of the outstanding shares of our limited liability company units, even if such amount is less than 50%, the Investor Group will continue to be able to strongly influence or effectively control our decisions.

Subsection Title: Changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to complex tax laws. Changes in tax laws could adversely affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments. We often rely on generally available interpretations of applicable tax laws and regulations. There cannot be certainty that the relevant tax authorities are in agreement with our interpretation of these laws. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations or our effective tax rate and have a negative effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The occurrence of any of the foregoing tax risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: While the issuers intend to treat interest paid on the USD secured notes tranche 2, the euro secured notes and the sterling secured notes as foreign source interest, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service may treat it as U.S. source.
Subsubsection Text: Although the issuers are co-issuing the notes, the net proceeds of the USD secured notes tranche 1 and the unsecured notes will be received and used by, and all amounts due on those notes are expected to be paid by, the Allied issuer, whereas the net proceeds of the USD secured notes tranche 2, the euro secured notes and the sterling secured notes will be received and used by, and all amounts due on such notes are expected to be paid by, the LuxCo co-issuer. For U.S. federal income tax purposes, the issuers intend to treat the USD secured notes tranche 1 and the unsecured notes as being issued by the Allied issuer and interest on such notes as U.S. source, and treat the USD secured notes tranche 2, the euro secured notes and the sterling secured notes as being issued by the LuxCo co-issuer and interest on such notes as foreign source.  However, there is no assurance that the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (the “IRS”) would not challenge such treatment. If the IRS were to successfully challenge such treatment, interest on the USD secured notes tranche 2, the euro secured notes and the sterling secured notes may be treated as U.S. source, and any non-U.S. investor holding such notes may be subject to withholding at 30%. -----

Subsection Title: The non-USD notes may not become, or remain, listed on the Exchange.
Subsubsection Text: Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the non-USD notes on the Official List of the Exchange. However, there can be no assurance that the non-USD notes will become or remain listed. If the issuers cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and the admission to dealing on the Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or maintain such listing, the issuers may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Exchange. Listing of any of the notes on the Exchange does not imply that a public offering of any of the notes in the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man has been authorized. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the non-USD notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for comparable issuers, failure to be approved for listing of the non-USD notes on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange or the delisting of the non-USD notes from the Official List of the Exchange or another listing exchange may have an adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell non-USD notes in the secondary market.

Subsection Title: You may face foreign currency exchange as a result of investing in the notes offered hereby.
Subsubsection Text: The euro secured notes will be denominated and payable in euro and the sterling secured notes will be denominated and payable in sterling. If you are a US investor, an investment in these notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro or sterling, as applicable relative to the US dollar because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro or sterling against the US dollar could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the relevant notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a US dollar basis.

Subsection Title: The terms of the ABL Credit Facility Increase have not yet been finalized and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities have not yet been fully syndicated.
Subsubsection Text: The credit agreement relating to the ABL Credit Facility Increase has not been finalized and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities have not yet been fully syndicated. Our ability to successfully syndicate the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and successfully obtain the ABL Credit Facility Increase is subject to market conditions and we cannot assure you that the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities or the ABL Credit Facility Increase will be successfully syndicated or obtained on the terms described herein. Future changes in market conditions may result in changes to the terms for the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the ABL Credit Facility Increase, including pricing, that are less favorable to us and may increase our interest expense and adversely affect our business. -----

_An investment in the notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the information included in this offering circular before deciding whether to purchase the notes. Any of the following risks may materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties that we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. In such a case, you may lose all or part of your original investment. The scale and scope of the COVID-19 pandemic may heighten the potential adverse effects on our business, results of operations and financial condition described in the risk factors discussed below. The risks discussed below also include forward-looking statements, and our actual results may differ substantially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. See “Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” in this offering circular._

Total gross purchase consideration[(4)(5)] ...................... $ 8,303 Estimated fees and expenses, net of foreign exchange impact .................................................... [$ ] 340 Estimated change in control costs .............................. $ 100 Cash to balance sheet ................................................. $ 742 Total uses .................................................................. $** 9,485 (1) Reflects an exchange rate from US$ to euro of 1.2151. (2) In connection with the Transactions, we entered into the New Revolving Credit Facility, which provides for a five-year senior secured revolving credit facility. The New Revolving Credit Facility provides for borrowings of up to €300 million outstanding at any one time. The New Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn at the closing of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities. See “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness” for a description of the New Revolving Credit Facility. (3) Represents the aggregate principal amount of the notes offered hereby and does not reflect the initial purchasers’ discount, fees or commissions. UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION (In USD thousands, except per share data and as otherwise noted) Note 1 – Description of Business Combination
Subsubsection Text: On April 6, 2021, Allied Bidco, a newly incorporated entity that is indirectly controlled by Allied Universal announced that its recommended Offer for G4S had become unconditional in all respects. Under the terms of the Offer, as set out in full in the offer document published by Allied Bidco dated January 5, 2021, G4S shareholders are entitled to receive 245 pence in cash for each G4S share (the G4S Acquisition). The Offer was made to G4S shareholders resident in the United States in reliance on, and compliance with, Section 14(e) of the US Exchange Act, and Regulation 14E thereunder, as a “Tier II” tender offer (as set forth in Rule 14d-1(d) under the US Exchange Act). On April 13, 2021, Allied Bidco announced that it had received acceptances under the Offer in respect of, or otherwise acquired, not less than 90% in value of the G4S shares to which the Offer relates and of the voting rights carried by those shares, and would therefore exercise its rights in accordance with the UK Companies Act 2006 to acquire compulsorily the remaining G4S shares in respect of which the Offer has not been accepted. In addition, Allied Universal, Allied Bidco and the G4S UK Pension Trustee of the G4S UK Pension Scheme entered into a Memorandum of Understanding setting out the parties’ intentions with respect to the future funding of the G4S UK Pension Scheme. Under the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding, in addition to certain support measures, Allied Universal will pay cash contributions to the G4S UK Pension Scheme based on a funding shortfall of approximately £535 million reflecting the higher funding target agreed with the G4S UK Pension Trustee. Allied Universal and the G4S UK Pension Trustee have also agreed on matters relating to the potential impact of the Offer and certain possible future disposals on the G4S UK Pension Scheme. Such commitment to funding per the Memorandum of Understanding is accounted for as a liability assumed in the application of purchase accounting under ASC 805.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The accompanying unaudited pro forma combined financial information is based on the historical financial statements of Allied Universal and G4S as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet as of December 31, 2020, and the unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2020, are presented herein. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet combines the unaudited consolidated balance sheets of Allied Universal and G4S as of December 31, 2020 and gives effect to the G4S Acquisition as if it occurred on December 31, 2020. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations combines the historical results of Allied Universal and G4S for the year ended December 31, 2020 and gives effect to the G4S Acquisition as if it occurred on January 1, 2020. The historical financial information has been adjusted to give effect to pro forma adjustments that address differences in reporting currencies, differences in bases of accounting, and differences in the classification and presentation of certain financial information and reflect transaction accounting adjustments, as well as other adjustments deemed to be directly related to the G4S Acquisition, irrespective of whether such adjustment is deemed to be recurring. Any adjustments for differences in bases of accounting are determined after taking into effect the impacts of purchase accounting. Allied Universal is deemed to be the accounting acquirer and the pro forma adjustments are preliminary and are based on estimates that are subject to change. The combined group will not be a “foreign private issuer” as defined in Rule 405 under the Securities Act and Rule 3b-4(c) under the Exchange Act. Accordingly, the pro forma information of the combined group is prepared in accordance with United States Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (“U.S. GAAP”). The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations was prepared using the historical audited consolidated statement of operations of Allied Universal for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the historical audited consolidated income statement of G4S for the year ended December 31, 2020. Allied Universal’s historical audited financial statements were prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and presented in thousands of U.S. dollars. G4S plc’s group consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the international accounting standards in conformity with the requirements of the UK Companies ----- Act 2006 and with international financial reporting standards adopted pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1606/2002 as it applies in the European Union (IFRS) and presented in millions of Sterling (GBP). Certain reclassifications were made to align G4S’s financial statement presentation with that of Allied Universal based on information available to date, (see Note 5). The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations also includes transaction related adjustments including certain purchase accounting adjustments, (see Note 6). Following the consummation of the G4S Acquisition, Allied Universal management will conduct a detailed review of the accounting for the G4S Acquisition and as a result of that review, Allied Universal management may identify differences that, when finalized, could have a material impact on the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Under the acquisition method of accounting, G4S’s assets and liabilities will be recorded at fair value at the date of acquisition and combined with the historical carrying amounts of Allied Universals’ assets and liabilities. For this purpose, fair value shall be determined in accordance with the fair value concepts defined in ASC 820, “Fair _Value Measurements and Disclosures,” (“ASC 820”). Fair value is defined in ASC 820 as “the price that would be_ received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.” Fair value measurements can be highly subjective and can involve a high degree of estimation. In the unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet, the purchase price paid by Allied Universal to acquire G4S has been allocated to the assets acquired, liabilities assumed and goodwill based upon management’s preliminary estimate of respective fair values as of December 31, 2020. Accordingly, the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information includes a preliminary allocation of the purchase price based on assumptions and estimates that, while considered reasonable under the circumstances, are subject to changes, which may be material. Allied Universal has not completed a full, detailed valuation analysis necessary to determine the fair values of G4S’s identifiable assets to be acquired, liabilities to be assumed and noncontrolling interest. The preliminary calculation of assets acquired and liabilities assumed performed for the purposes of these unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial statements was primarily limited to the identification and calculation of preliminary values for the intangible assets and deferred taxes. The calculations necessary to estimate the fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed have been performed based on proprietary benchmarking information, publicly available information, as well as a variety of other assumptions, including market participant assumptions. Where practicable, the benchmark information was corroborated with an income approach methodology. Allied Universal ----- will continue to refine its identification and valuation of assets acquired and liabilities assumed as further information becomes available. Refer to Note 6E for the range of fair value estimates of assets acquired and liabilities assumed. The final determination of the purchase price allocation is anticipated to be completed as soon as practicable and will be based on the fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the acquisition closing date. The final amounts allocated to assets acquired and liabilities assumed could differ significantly from the amounts presented in the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial statements. Such final allocation could result in significantly different amortization and depreciation expense due to differing allocations of purchase price between definite versus indefinite lived intangible assets, or depreciating tangible assets. The purchase price is allocated to the underlying assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on the midpoint of their respective estimated fair values, with any excess purchase price allocated to goodwill as follows (in USD thousands): Cash consideration .................................................................................................. **$** **5,324,451 Cash and Cash Equivalents ..................................................................................... 2,049,716 Accounts receivable, net ......................................................................................... 1,197,734 Other assets acquired ............................................................................................... 1,848,298 Identifiable intangible assets acquired .................................................................... 2,484,901

Subsubsection Text: (1) Allied Universal incurred a liability that is an estimated $773 million in cash payments to be made by Allied Universal through fiscal year 2026 in order to fund an existing deficit in the G4S pension scheme. $177 million is reflected on the balance sheet in Accrued expenses and other current liabilities, and the remaining $596 million is reflected in Other liabilities, and represents payments to be made between fiscal years 2022 and 2026. Further, as any deduction related to pension plan contributions would result in a net operating loss (“NOL”) and the Combined Company has no expectation of realizing the benefit of such NOL due to it being a loss making entity, no deferred tax asset was recorded.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The following adjustments have been made to align G4S’s historical balance sheet as of December 31, 2020 and statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2020 to Allied Universal’s accounting policies after taking into effect the impacts of purchase accounting: B.** **Uniforms.** Represents an adjustment to record a reversal of accumulated depreciation related to capitalized uniform costs as Allied Universal’s policy is to depreciate uniforms over three years whereas G4S expenses uniforms over two years. The balance sheet impact is an estimated increase of $21.8 million to Property and equipment, net, offset by a $5.5 million decrease to Deferred tax assets. The net impact to the statement of operations is an estimated reduction of $2.6 million to Direct expenses.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsection Title: C.** **Leases. Represents an adjustment to record the reversal of G4S’s lease related balances recognized
Subsubsection Text: in accordance with IFRS 16 – Leases (“IFRS 16”) to align with the recognition of leases under ASC 840, _Leases (“ASC 840”), as applied by Allied Universal. The balance sheet impact results in a derecognition of Right of use assets (Property and equipment, net) and net investments in finance lease assets (Deposits and other long-term assets) of $309.3 million and $8.2 million, respectively, that was offset by an additional recognition of $17.7 million of net investment in finance lease asset in Property and equipment, net. There was an additional derecognition of a short-term and longterm IFRS 16 lease liability of $118.6 million and $260.3 million, respectively, offset by a recognition of short-term and long-term finance (capital) lease liabilities per ASC 840 of $6.8 ----- million and $19.1 million, respectively. There was a further derecognition of Deferred tax assets of $19.1 million to reflect the tax impacts of the reversals. The net impact to the statement of operations involves a reversal of depreciation on right of use assets presented as Direct expenses of $63.1 million, a reversal of General and administrative expenses of $42.1 million, and a reversal of Interest expense recognized on lease liabilities of $22.6 million. Such reversal has been offset by the recognition of operating lease rental expenses presented in Direct expenses and in General and administrative expenses of $84.2 million and $54.9 million, respectively. D.** **Goodwill Impairment.** Represents an adjustment to record a reversal of goodwill impairment analyzed at the cash generating unit level per International Accounting Standards Board (“IAS”) 36 - Impairment of Assets due to the expectation that impairment analysis at the reporting unit level per U.S. GAAP would not result in any impairment. The adjustment results in an increase to Goodwill of $78.7 million on the balance sheet, and a corresponding reversal of Goodwill impairment of $74.1 million, net of $4.6 million of currency translation impact on the statement of operations.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsection Title: E.** **Onerous Contracts. Represents an adjustment to remove the current and non-current provision of
Subsubsection Text: $4.1 million and $24.5 million, respectively, relating to onerous contracts recognized by G4S in accordance with IAS 37 – Provisions (“IAS 37”) but not recognized under U.S. GAAP. This balance sheet impact is offset by an associated $5.5 million reduction in the Deferred tax asset balance. To record the impact of the reversal of onerous contract provision balances in the statement of operations for the period ended December 31, 2020, the expense of $9.0 million recognized during 2020 for future losses is reversed from General and administration expense and is instead, recognized as an in-year loss in Direct expense. F.** **Defined Benefit Schemes.** Represents an adjustment to record a $61.6 million increase in Other expense, net. This adjustment also results in an additional tax expense of $7.7 million. There is no balance sheet impact as a result of this adjustment, as any adjustments made to Other comprehensive income would be eliminated due to the application of purchase accounting.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsection Title: G.** **Hedge Accounting. Represents an adjustment to record $21.8 million in Interest expense as a result
Subsubsection Text: of the unwinding of hedge accounting from Other comprehensive income into Interest expense. This adjustment results in an associated tax expense of $6.4 million. There is no balance sheet impact as a result of this adjustment, as any adjustments made to Other comprehensive income would be eliminated due to the application of purchase accounting. H.** **Cloud Computing Costs.** Represents an adjustment to reverse a balance of $31.3 million from Intangible assets, net for capitalized implementation costs on cloud computing software provided to G4S as a service. Such costs are not capitalizable for entities such as Allied Universal who have not yet adopted ASU 2018-15. This reversal is offset by an associated $8.2 million increase in deferred tax assets. I.** **Unremitted Earnings.** Represents an adjustment of $47.4 million to record the recognition of deferred tax on unremitted earnings in accordance with ASC 740.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On April 6, 2021, Allied Bidco, a newly incorporated entity that is indirectly controlled by Allied Universal announced that its recommended Offer for G4S had become unconditional in all respects. Under the terms of the Offer, as set out in full in the offer document published by Allied Bidco dated January 5, 2021, G4S shareholders are entitled to receive 245 pence in cash for each G4S share. The Offer was made to G4S shareholders resident in the United States in reliance on, and compliance with, Section 14(e) of the US Exchange Act, and Regulation 14E thereunder, as a “Tier II” tender offer (as set forth in Rule 14d-1(d) under the US Exchange Act). The acquisition of G4S will be accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting as per the provisions of Accounting Standards Codification 805, “Business Combinations” (“ASC 805”), with Allied Universal representing the accounting acquirer under this guidance. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial statements were prepared to illustrate the estimated effects of the acquisition. For each of the periods presented, the pro forma financial information reflects the combination of historical financial information of Allied Universal and G4S, adjusted to give effect to the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with ASC 805 based on a preliminary purchase price allocation, and as subsequently described in greater detail. Furthermore, additional pro forma adjustments have also been reflected to show impacts of financing to effect the acquisition, addresses differences in reporting currencies, differences in bases of accounting, and differences in the classification and presentation of certain financial information, and shows the effects of the adoption of certain accounting standards. For purposes of certain disclosures that follow, Allied Universal and G4S may be referred to collectively as the “Combined Company.” The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet as of December 31, 2020, and the unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2020, are presented herein. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet combines the unaudited consolidated balance sheets of Allied Universal and G4S as of December 31, 2020 and gives effect to the acquisition and financing for the acquisition as if it occurred on December 31, 2020. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations combines the historical results of Allied Universal and G4S for the year ended December 31, 2020 and gives effect to the acquisition as if it occurred on January 1, 2020. The historical financial information has been adjusted to give effect to pro forma adjustments that address differences in reporting currencies, differences in bases of accounting, differences in the classification and presentation of certain financial information, and the adoption of certain accounting standards. The pro forma adjustments included in this document are subject to modification based on the final determination of the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, additional analysis, and additional information that may become available, which may cause the final adjustments to be materially different from the pro forma condensed combined financial statements presented below. Following the consummation of the G4S Acquisition, Allied Universal management will perform a detailed review of G4S’s accounting policies in an effort to determine if differences in accounting policies require further reclassification of G4S’s results of operations or reclassification of assets or liabilities to conform to Allied Universal’s accounting policies and classification. As a result, Allied Universal may subsequently identify additional material differences in the accounting policies which could have a material impact on the unaudited pro forma combined financial information. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information presented is for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the financial position or results of operations that would have been realized if the G4S Acquisition had been completed on the dates set forth above, nor is it indicative of future results or financial position of the combined company. Additionally, the final determination of the purchase price and the purchase price allocation, upon the completion of the G4S Acquisition, will be based on G4S’s net assets acquired as of that date and will depend on a number of factors that cannot be predicted with certainty at this time. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information does not reflect any anticipated synergies or dissynergies, operating efficiencies or cost savings that may result from the G4S Acquisition or potential divestitures that may occur prior to, or subsequent to, the completion of the G4S Acquisition or any acquisition and integration costs that may be incurred. The pro forma adjustments, which Allied Universal believes are reasonable under the circumstances, are preliminary and are based upon available information and certain assumptions described in the accompanying notes to the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information. Actual results and ----- valuations may differ materially from the assumptions within the accompanying unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information should be read in conjunction with the notes to the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information and G4S’s audited financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020 below, as well as Allied Universal’s audited consolidated financial statements and related notes thereto for the year ended December 31, 2020. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Allied Universal is North America’s leading security and facility services provider. With over 250,000 security professionals and offices located throughout the United States as well as internationally (Canada, Mexico, and the United Kingdom), Allied Universal serves approximately 14,800 clients and is responsible for protecting more than 50,000 client sites covering multiple specialty sectors such as higher education, healthcare, retail, commercial real estate, government, and corporate campuses, including a significant portion of the Fortune 500 companies. Allied Universal’s services span manned guarding, innovative technology systems, risk and consulting, janitorial and staffing services, integration services, and digital solutions and remote monitoring. We are responsible for providing “best-in-class” security services that allow clients to completely outsource the recruiting, screening, hiring, training, uniforming, scheduling and supervision of security officers. Our security officers work on-location at customer sites and are responsible for observing, detecting, deterring and reporting and responding to perceived, potential or actual security threats. We also provide specialized security services such as vehicle patrol, visitor management, K-9 security services, top security facility cleared security professionals, and joint security programs. We have an operational presence in all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and have a growing presence in Canada, Latin America, and the United Kingdom. In addition to providing manned guarding services, we provide comprehensive technology solutions to our customers, including video surveillance, CCTV picture capture and monitoring, robot patrolling, GPS-based patrol and reporting, management of access control points and centralized security operations. We also offer systems integration services to design, install and service fully integrated technology-based monitoring systems, along with digital solutions and remote monitoring through our MaRC. We are able to leverage our large manned guarding customer base and service platform to cross-sell these additional system integration services. Finally, we offer a range of ancillary services, including temporary and permanent staffing, event staffing and security, janitorial services, and consulting and investigation solutions. Allied Universal was formed in August 2016 through the combination of AlliedBarton and Universal, which brought together two of the leading providers in the security services industry. AlliedBarton, founded in 1957, and Universal, founded in 1965, were leaders in the industry in customer service, organic growth, customer and employee retention, accretive M&A, and had a highly complementary and diverse set of blue chip customers. The combined company became the largest provider of security officer services in North America and has continued to grow since, both organically and through M&A. In the fourth quarter of 2018, Allied Universal acquired U.S. Security Associates Holdings, Inc., a leading North American provider of security solutions, including manned security, consulting, investigations, and disaster and emergency response services. Since 2007, the company has successfully executed 72 acquisitions, including small and large tuck-ins. In the fourth quarter of 2019, Allied announced the acquisition of SOS Security, which brought a complementary approach and further scale to Allied Universal. As of 2020, Allied Universal has an estimated 31% share of the highly fragmented outsourced manned guarding security services market in the United States, with a track record of growth driven both organically and through acquisitions. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On February 3, 2020, we issued an additional $540.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing 2026 Secured Notes under an indenture dated July 12, 2019 (the “Existing Secured Indenture”) with Wilmington Trust, National Association, as the Trustee and as the Notes Collateral Agent. The additional Secured Notes were issued in a private transaction that was not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act. Holders of the additional Secured Notes are not entitled to any registration rights. The proceeds from the additional Secured Notes were used to repay the outstanding borrowings under the ABL Credit Facility and provide working capital and funds for other general corporate purposes of the Company. During March 2020, we borrowed $500.0 million under the ABL Credit Facility out of an abundance of caution in response to the novel coronavirus (“COVID-19”) pandemic. After not using any of the additional cash provided by this borrowing, we repaid the $500.0 million in full during August 2020. On March 27, 2020, the U.S. government enacted the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (the “CARES Act”). The CARES Act is an emergency economic stimulus package in response to the COVID-19 pandemic which, among other things, contains numerous income tax provisions. The CARES Act allows us to defer the payment of the employer share of social security taxes for the period beginning March 27, 2020 through December 31, 2020. Based on the CARES Act, we deferred $282.0 million of qualified payroll tax payments as of December 31, 2020, of which $141.0 million is recorded within accrued payroll and related taxes and $141.0 million is recorded within other liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet. The current portion of this liability is due by December 31, 2021 with the remainder due by December 31, 2022. Additionally, we were able to deduct additional Section 163(j) interest carryforward amounts as a result of the increase in the limitation provided by the CARES Act. We will continue to monitor future guidance issued regarding the CARES Act to determine any future impacts. On April 29, 2020, Wendel SE sold its remaining ownership interest in Allied Universal to the new investment group led by Warburg Pincus LLC and an affiliate of the J. Safra Group. On July 15, 2020, we issued an additional $400.0 million aggregate principal amount of Secured Notes under the Secured Indenture with Wilmington Trust, National Association, as the Trustee and as the Notes Collateral Agent. The additional Secured Notes were issued in a private transaction that was not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act. Holders of the additional Secured Notes are not entitled to any registration rights. The proceeds from the additional Secured Notes were used to provide working capital and funds for other general corporate purposes of the Company. On July 17, 2020, we acquired substantially all of the assets of Phoenix Systems & Service, Inc. (PSSI) for an initial purchase price subject to certain post-closing adjustments of $13.9 million. PSSI is a full-service security systems integrator based in Chicago, Illinois, and provides security solutions to customers in Chicago and across the United States. On August 31, 2020, we acquired substantially all of the assets of Summit Security Services, Inc. (Summit) for an initial purchase price subject to certain post-closing adjustments of $48.3 million. Summit is a security services company that provides services to customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. On August 31, 2020, we acquired substantially all of the assets of Service Works Inc. (Service Works) for an initial purchase price subject to certain post-closing adjustments of $7.2 million. Service Works is a full-service security systems integrator based in Farmingdale, New Jersey and provides security solutions to customers in the Northeast and throughout the United States. On October 1, 2020, we acquired the assets of the Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport (BWI) security operation of Akal Security, Inc. (“Akal”), including its contract with BWI, for $1.0 million. On October 16, 2020, we acquired substantially all of the assets of Safe Environment Business Solutions, Inc. (SEB) for an initial purchase price subject to certain post-closing adjustments of $31.8 million, including contingent consideration of $9.8 million, which is subject to be paid based on achievement of certain targets after the ----- acquisition date, and of which $5.0 million was paid in December 2020. Based in Ossining, New York, SEB provides customized security solutions, including man-guarding, to customers throughout the United States. On November 20, 2020, we acquired substantially all of the assets of Platt Security, Incorporated (“Platt”) for an initial purchase price subject to certain post-closing adjustments of $3.7 million, including contingent consideration of $1.1 million, which is subject to be paid based on achievement of certain targets after the acquisition date. Platt is based in Long Beach, California and provides security services for public events, gated residential communities, public housing developments, commercial buildings and shopping centers. On December 27, 2020, The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021 (“CAA”) was signed into law. The CAA clarifies and expands the Paycheck Protection Program loans and the Employee Retention Credit as well as several other tax provisions first outlined in the CARES Act. The CAA is currently being evaluated, however, we do not anticipate a material impact as a result of this legislation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Characteristics of Allied Universal’s Revenues and Expenses Revenues
Subsubsection Text: We generate revenues primarily from customer contracts obligating us to provide security officer services at agreed-upon hourly billing rates. Our standard customer contract has a one-year term but may be terminated by either our customer or us with 30 days’ advance notice. Many of our larger contracts are multi-year but also allow for cancellation by either party with 30 to 90 days’ advance notice. We base our customer billings on the underlying contractual terms, which generally include a mark-up on wages paid or a stated bill rate for hours worked. The majority of our customers are billed a rate per hour worked which includes wages and benefits. We generally bill our customers either in advance, weekly, bi-weekly or monthly. Our revenue growth in the year ended December 31, 2020 over the corresponding period was driven by acquisitions, as well as organic revenue growth related to bill-rate improvements. Our organic revenue growth is driven primarily by our ability to maintain strong customer retention rates and to attract new customers. Our contract security officer revenues and high retention rates are dependent on our ability to attract and retain high-quality, qualified employees. Our wage rates are generally above market averages, and we provide our security officers with benefits at a higher level than many of our competitors. In addition, we engage in extensive candidate screening, training and development, which supports employee retention. We believe our employee retention rate compares favorably to the average retention rates in our industry. In turn, this has allowed us to realize higher than average customer bill rates. In addition to our security officer services, we provide security system, janitorial and other ancillary services for our customers. Our security systems solutions include consulting, design and engineering, installation, and event and repair services for security systems. These revenue streams represented approximately 6% of our total revenue during the year ended December 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Direct expenses are comprised primarily of direct labor, payroll taxes, medical and life insurance benefits, workers’ compensation costs, general liability, employment practices liability and automobile insurance costs, and subcontract labor and other direct expenses. We classify all of our security officer wages and our account manager compensation and payroll-related expenses as direct expenses. Compensation paid includes regular pay, overtime pay for hourly personnel, bonus, vacation, training, holiday and sick time. The total hours paid normally exceeds total hours billed principally due to unbillable overtime and certain other unbillable costs. We believe that we have higher wage and benefit costs than other companies in our industry, due to our focus on attracting, developing and retaining a highly qualified workforce. ----- General wage inflation, payroll tax rate and related taxable wage threshold changes, and insurance premiums and related claim costs are the primary drivers that affect the major components of direct expenses. Traditionally, we have been able to pass increased costs in these areas on to our customers. Our payroll tax expenses historically are higher in the first half of the year because a significant number of employees do not reach their taxable wage limits for employer related federal and state unemployment taxes until the second half of the year. Medical benefit costs for the majority of our workforce consist of premium-based insurance costs. Conversely, for administrative employees and security officers not subject to premium-based coverage, we are selfinsured and subject to self-insured retention limits. See “Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates” for further discussion.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Allied Universal’s Performance
Subsubsection Text: We believe the following trends and factors have an important impact on our financial performance: - Continued growth in the security market: Due to increased occurrences of adverse safety and security events affecting the general public, continued wage growth, and increased outsourced services penetration, we continue to see growth in the total size of the security market in the United States and globally. As a marketleading provider of security services and technology solutions, overall industry growth is a factor driving our business. As such, our financial results are significantly affected by overall industry growth. - Increasing pressure on customer pricing combined with a competitive labor market: The security market is intensely competitive as there are relatively low barriers to entry. We compete directly with companies that are local, regional, national and international in scope. As more customers select service providers through competitive bid processes intended to procure quality services at lower prices, our customer retention may be affected as new market competitors may be willing to provide services at lower prices and margins. In addition, we face pressure to increase compensation and benefits for employees as we compete with other companies for the same workforce. Our ability to retain customers is dependent on our ability to hire, train and retain employees at scale while efficiently deploying our workforce to efficiently meet our customers’ security service needs. - Our ability to deliver comprehensive, integrated security solutions and expand the use of technology: Increasingly, our clients are asking us for more complex technology solutions and security operations services. As such, we believe that our success will be based on our ability to tailor specific, innovative solutions to meet the changing needs of our clients. - Our sales performance and ability to execute on strategy: The number of clients that we add in a given period impacts our longer-term revenue. We are focused on attracting new clients, and expanding our service offerings at existing clients. Furthermore, our ability to continue to pass along rate increases to our customers will protect our margins but in part, could be offset by reduced hours. - Our continued ability to acquire and integrate accretive targets: Since 2007, and as of December 31, 2020, we have acquired 73 businesses. Our acquisition process allows us to integrate targets, while minimizing client disruption. Furthermore, we view expansion into international and adjacent markets to be an opportunity driving future growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Subsubsection Text: Direct expenses .............................................................. $ 7,356,020 $ 6,588,222 $ 767,798 11.7% Direct expenses increased by $767.8 million, or 11.7%, for the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in direct expenses is primarily due to the increase in revenues of ----- 13.9%, partially offset by reduced insurance and overtime costs, as well as improved employee retention which results in a reduction of training and recruiting costs, reduced payroll taxes and less unbillable overtime. Direct expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased to 86.5% for the year ended December 31, 2020 from 88.3% for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease in direct expenses as a percentage of revenues is the result of COVID-19 related premium services and the redeployment of displaced workers to reduce overtime expenses beginning toward the end of March and through December 31, 2020, as well as longer-term operational improvements made in our business during the year ended December 31, 2020, such as increases in bill-rates and the successful implementation of workforce management initiatives resulting in lower non-billable overtime. While we are seeing a return of hours to pre-COVID levels, we are also seeing a reduction of premium services, particularly during the fourth quarter of 2020. It is uncertain how long the current situation will continue in this evolving environment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. The preparation of the financial statements requires management to make certain estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. We base these estimates, judgments and assumptions on historical experience and on other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. We believe the following critical policies affect our more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The cost of an acquired business is assigned to the tangible and intangible assets purchased and liabilities assumed on the basis of their fair values at the date of acquisition. The determination of fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed requires us to make estimates and use valuation techniques when a market value is not readily available. Any excess of purchase price over the fair value of tangible and intangible assets acquired and obligations assumed is allocated to goodwill. Goodwill typically represents the value paid for the assembled workforce and enhancement of our service offerings. As part of certain completed acquisitions, we may agree to pay cash to the sellers based upon achievement of certain targets after the acquisition date. The fair values of these contingent consideration arrangements are estimated using a probability weighted income approach. We evaluate the fair value of the contingent consideration throughout the year and every reporting period. Changes in the fair value during the measurement period that pertain ----- to facts and circumstances that existed as of the acquisition date are recorded as measurement period adjustments to goodwill. Changes in the fair value resulting from events that occurred after the acquisition date are recorded as a gain or loss on changes in fair value of the contingent purchase consideration in the consolidated statements of operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We offer our products and services to public and private sector customers. The financial condition of our customers is affected by changes in general economic conditions as well as by other economic pressures in the markets in which our customers operate. We believe that the credit risk associated with our trade accounts receivable is mitigated by the fact that our customer base is diverse and geographically dispersed within North America. We do not require collateral for trade receivables; however, we monitor our customer relationships in order to minimize our credit risk. We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers’ financial condition and maintain an allowance for doubtful accounts based on a culmination of factors. These factors include: (1) customer creditworthiness, (2) aging of accounts receivable, (3) past transaction history with the customer, (4) current economic industry trends and (5) changes in customer payment terms. If the financial condition of our customers were to deteriorate, adversely affecting their ability to make payments, we would provide additional allowances. Changes in these factors, among others, may lead to adjustments in our allowance for doubtful accounts. The calculation of the allowance requires judgment as to the impact of those and other factors on the ultimate realization of trade accounts receivable. We writeoff trade accounts receivable to the allowance for doubtful accounts when we determine collection is unlikely and we have ceased our collection efforts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Long-lived assets include identifiable intangibles with finite lives (such as customer relationships) and property and equipment. We review our long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. Such events and circumstances include, among other factors: - current period operating losses or negative cash flow combined with a history of similar losses or forecasts indicating continuing losses associated with the use of an asset, - significant decreases in the market value of an asset, - technological developments resulting in obsolescence, - significant changes in demand for our services in competition and competitive practices, or - significant negative changes in the business climate, industry or economic conditions. Recoverability of our long-lived assets is determined based upon the expected undiscounted future net cash flows from the operations to which the assets relate, utilizing our best estimates, appropriate assumptions, and projections at the time of review. If the carrying value is determined not to be recoverable from future operating cash flows, the asset is deemed impaired, and an impairment loss would be recognized to the extent the carrying value exceeded the estimated fair market value of the asset.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Goodwill and Indefinite-lived Intangible Asset Impairment
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are not amortized; rather, they are tested for impairment annually as of October 1. For goodwill, which we have determined is a single reporting unit, we may conduct an assessment of qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount. In a qualitative assessment, we would consider the macroeconomic conditions, including any deterioration of general conditions and industry and market conditions, including any deterioration in the environment where the reporting unit operates, increased competition, changes in the products/services and regulatory and political developments, cost of doing business, overall financial performance, including any declining cash flows and performance in relation to planned revenues and earnings in past periods, other relevant reporting unit specific facts, such as changes in management or key personnel or pending litigation, and events affecting the reporting unit, including changes in the carrying value of net assets. If we determine that it is more likely than not that the fair ----- value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying value, then we would perform the quantitative goodwill impairment test as required. If we determine that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying value, then no further testing is required. If the carrying amount exceeds the fair value then we would record an impairment loss in an amount equal to that excess, limited to the total amount of goodwill allocated to the reporting unit. We estimate the fair value of our reporting unit based on a combination of significant observable and unobservable inputs, including estimates of future operating performance. Changes in market conditions, among other factors, may have an impact on these estimates. For our indefinite-lived trade names, we may also conduct an assessment of qualitative factors to determine whether or not it is more likely than not that the fair value of the assets is less than their carrying value. If we determine that it is more likely than not that the fair value of the trade names is less than their carrying value, we estimate the fair value of our indefinite-lived trade names using the relief from royalty method. The relief from royalty method measures the discounted cash flow savings realized from owning such intangible assets and not having to pay a royalty for their use. Impairment would then be recognized for the difference between the determined fair value and their carrying value, if applicable.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We maintain insurance coverage, subject to certain self-insured retention limits, for workers’ compensation, general liability, employment practices liability, automobile liability and healthcare claims. Medical benefit costs for the majority of our workforce are premium-based. Costs associated with the premium-based plans equal the actual premiums paid and premiums can fluctuate. Conversely, for administrative employees and security officers not subject to premium-based coverage, we are self-insured and subject to self-insured retention limits. We record a reserve if we believe it is probable that we have incurred a liability and we can reasonably estimate the amount of the loss. We provide a reserve for all known claims and those claims that we believe have been incurred but not reported as of the balance sheet date based on our estimate of the ultimate cost of the claims. Our estimates of the ultimate cost of claims are derived from the level of our insurance coverages, our retained risk of loss, third-party actuarial analyses and management’s judgment. We review these estimates on a quarterly basis subject to information then currently available to assess their adequacy and the propriety of disclosure. We adjust the reserves, if needed, based on the results of our review. Assessing the adequacy of these reserves is highly subjective and requires judgments about future events. The amount of the actual loss may differ significantly from these estimates. In the normal course of operations, various legal claims are filed against the Company for which we maintain insurance coverage. We have reserved for these claims based on insurance coverage, the risk of loss retained by the Company and management’s judgment. We do not expect the ultimate outcome of any of these actions to have a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Equity unit-based compensation costs are measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the equity award using an appropriate option-pricing method and are recognized in the statements of operations over the period during which an employee is required to provide service in exchange for the award. This expense is presented as a separate line item under operating costs and expenses in the consolidated statements of operations. We use an independent valuation advisor to assist with determining the fair value of the equity awards used for calculating equity unit-based compensation. We consider both the historical volatility of our peer group’s stock prices, as well as implied volatilities from exchange-traded options on our peer group’s equity units, as applicable. The expected term used represents the period that the equity units are expected to be outstanding and is determined using the simplified method. The assumptions used in calculating the fair value of equity unit-based awards represent management’s best estimates, but these estimates involve inherent uncertainties and the application of management’s judgment. As a result, if factors change and different assumptions were used, equity unit-based compensation could materially differ in the future. In addition, we are required to estimate the expected forfeiture rate as well as achievement of any performance metric specified within the award, and only recognize expense for those units expected to vest. If the actual forfeiture rate or expected achievement of the performance metric is materially different ----- from its estimate, the equity unit-based compensation expense could be significantly different from what we have recorded in the current period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Within our financial reporting structure there are legal entities treated as partnerships and C-corporations that are both consolidated and treated separately for federal and state income tax reporting purposes. The legal entities that are treated as partnerships for federal and state income tax purposes pass their taxable income or loss through to the members who report their share of the income or loss which has been allocated to them under the respective membership agreements. The membership agreements have provisions requiring the distribution of funds to the members in amounts sufficient for the members to satisfy their federal, state, and local tax obligations with respect to their share of our income, subject to board approval. The legal entities that are treated as C-corporations calculate an income tax provision or benefit for the current income taxes and deferred income tax assets and liabilities as a result of differences between the accounting and tax treatment of items related to these entities. Where, based on the weight of available evidence, it is more likely than not that some amount of a recorded deferred tax asset will not be realized, a valuation allowance is established for the amount sufficient to reduce that deferred tax asset to an amount that is more likely than not to be realized. We file U.S. federal, state, and foreign tax returns. Tax returns for years beginning in 2017 are subject to audit by the Internal Revenue Service and various tax authorities. While we have accrued for amounts we believe are in accordance with the accounting standard, the final outcome with a tax authority may result in a tax liability that is more or less than that reflected in the consolidated financial statements. Furthermore, we may later decide to challenge any assessments, if made, and may exercise our right to appeal. Uncertain tax positions are reviewed annually with guidance provided in ASC Topic 740, Income Taxes for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return that directly or indirectly affect amounts reported in financial statements. ASC Topic 740 also provides accounting guidance for the related income tax effects of individual tax positions that do not meet the recognition thresholds required in order for any part of the benefit of that tax position to be recognized in an entity’s financial statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2020, we had $970.9 million in cash and $1,640.7 million in working capital. Our liquidity requirements are principally for debt service, working capital and potential acquisitions. Our primary source of liquidity is cash provided by operating and financing activities. We also had $300.0 million and $607.1 million available for borrowing under our Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility, respectively, as of December 31, 2020, that provide additional liquidity to the Company as needed.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On July 12, 2019, we refinanced our debt and entered into certain senior secured credit facilities (the “Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities”), which consist of (i) a $2,020.0 million seven year senior secured term loan facility (the “Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility”) and a delayed draw term loan facility providing borrowings of up to $200.0 million (the “Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility”), (ii) a $300.0 million five year senior secured revolving credit facility (the “Existing Revolving Credit Facility”) and (iii) a $750.0 million five year asset based lending credit facility. The Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility was fully drawn on July 12, 2019. Contemporaneously with the entry into the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, we issued (i) $1,000.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing 2026 Secured Notes under an indenture dated July 12, 2019 (the “Existing Secured Indenture”) and (ii) $1,050.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes under an indenture dated July 12, 2019 (the “Existing Unsecured Indenture”) with Wilmington Trust, National Association, as trustee (the “Trustee”) and as notes collateral agent (the “Notes Collateral Agent”). The Existing 2026 Secured Notes and Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes were issued in a private transaction that was not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act. Holders of the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes are not entitled to any registration rights and the Secured Indenture and Unsecured Indenture are not qualified under the Trust Indenture Act. ----- The proceeds from the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes were used to (i) repay in full all outstanding borrowings under the then existing 2015 facility, (ii) redeem in full all borrowings under the then existing second lien note purchase agreement, (iii) pay related fees, costs, premiums and expenses in connection with these transactions (such transactions, the “Refinancing”), (iv) cash collateralize, replace or provide credit support for certain existing letters of credit outstanding and (v) provide working capital and funds for our other general corporate purposes (and certain fees and expenses related thereto). The Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility was fully drawn on December 30, 2019 in connection with the acquisition of SOS. In connection with the Refinancing, we recognized a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $88.3 million, which includes the write-off of existing deferred financing fees that had a carrying value of $62.4 million, $17.7 million of un-accreted original issue discount and $8.2 million of fees paid to noteholders in connection with the notes redemption. In connection with the Refinancing, we also capitalized an additional $88.5 million of financing fees, including $59.0 million of original issue discount. On February 3, 2020, we issued an additional $540.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing 2026 Secured Notes under the Existing Secured Indenture with Wilmington Trust, National Association, as the Trustee and as the Notes Collateral Agent. The additional Existing 2026 Secured Notes were issued in a private transaction that was not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act. Holders of the additional Existing 2026 Secured Notes are not entitled to any registration rights. In connection with the issuance, we capitalized $25.7 million of original issue premium. The proceeds from the additional Existing 2026 Secured Notes were used to repay the outstanding borrowings under the ABL Credit Facility and provide working capital and funds for other general corporate purposes of the Company. During March 2020, we borrowed $500.0 million under the ABL Credit Facility out of an abundance of caution in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. After not using any of the additional cash provided by this borrowing, we repaid the $500.0 million in full during August 2020. On July 15, 2020, we issued an additional $400.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing 2026 Secured Notes under the Existing Secured Indenture with Wilmington Trust, National Association, as the Trustee and as the Notes Collateral Agent. The additional Existing 2026 Secured Notes were issued in a private transaction that was not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act. Holders of the additional Existing 2026 Secured Notes are not entitled to any registration rights. In connection with the issuance, we capitalized $12.0 million of original issue premium. The proceeds from the additional Existing 2026 Secured Notes were used to provide working capital and funds for other general corporate purposes of the Company. Outstanding balances under the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility, Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility and Existing Revolving Credit Facility accrue interest equal to, at our option: (a) LIBOR plus 4.25% or (b) at the bank’s prime rate plus between 2.75% and 3.25% based on a first lien leverage calculation. Amounts drawn on the ABL Credit Facility accrue interest equal to, at our option: (a) LIBOR plus between 1.25% and 1.75% or (b) at the bank’s prime rate, plus between 0.25% and 0.75%. We incur a fixed 4.25% fee on all outstanding issued letters of credit (“LoCs”) pledged against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and incur a 1.25% or 1.50% fee on all outstanding issued LoCs pledged against the ABL Credit Facility. In addition, we incur a fixed 0.125% issuer fee on all outstanding LoCs pledged against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility. Outstanding balances under the Existing 2026 Secured Notes accrue interest at an annual rate of 6.625%. Outstanding balances under the Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes accrue interest at an annual rate of 9.750%. Principal on the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility and Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility is payable in equal quarterly installments of 0.25% of the original aggregate principal amounts, with the remaining unpaid balances due on July 12, 2026, the maturity date. All unpaid balances of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility are due and payable on July 12, 2024, the maturity dates. All unpaid balances of the Existing 2026 Secured Notes are due and payable on July 15, 2026, the maturity date. All unpaid balances of the Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes are due and payable on July 15, 2027, the maturity date. The Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility and Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility also contain provisions for potential additional principal payments based on excess cash flow for years commencing with the year ended December 31, 2020. We determined that an ----- additional principal payment based on excess cash flow was not required for the year ended December 31, 2020. Voluntary prepayments of amounts outstanding under the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility, the Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility, the Existing Secured Indenture and the Existing Unsecured Indenture are permitted under certain circumstances. Borrowings under the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility, the Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility, and the Existing Secured Indenture are secured by substantially all of our assets. The Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility, the Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility, the Existing Secured Indenture and Existing Unsecured Indenture contain customary restrictive covenants, which include maintaining a defined leverage ratio and restrictions on distributions to members. Under the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities, we may issue up to $100.0 million in LoCs against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and another $400.0 million against the ABL Credit Facility. Availability under both the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility is reduced by outstanding revolver-funded LoCs, which serve primarily as collateral for our workers’ compensation and general liability insurance policies. As of December 31, 2020, the total amount of LoCs pledged against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility was $0 and $142.9 million, respectively. As of December 31, 2019, the total amount of LoCs pledged against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility was $1.0 million and $115.9 million, respectively. The amount available for borrowing under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility at December 31, 2020 was $300.0 million and $607.1 million, respectively. The amount available for borrowing under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility at December 31, 2019 was $299.0 million and $229.1 million, respectively. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, $8.0 million and $10.3 million, respectively, of unamortized deferred financing fees was included in deposits and other long-term assets and $20.8 million and $21.2 million, respectively, of unamortized deferred financing fees was presented as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of the related debt liability and included in long-term debt in the consolidated balance sheets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 was $595.1 million and cash used in operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 was $15.9 million. For the year ended December 31, 2020, cash provided by operating activities was generated from net losses of $84.3 million adjusted for non-cash expenses of $360.1 million as well as changes in working capital of $319.3 million, which is inclusive of $282.0 million of qualified payroll tax payment deferrals from the CARES Act. CARES Act payroll tax deferrals are due to be repaid by December 31, 2021 and 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2019, cash used in operating activities was generated from net losses of $381.6 million adjusted for non-cash expenses of $441.0 million as well as changes in working capital of $(75.3) million. Cash paid for interest for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 was $312.5 million and $228.9 million, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Cash used in investing activities for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 was $148.6 million and $796.8 million, respectively. During the year ended December 31, 2020, we paid approximately $98.2 million (net of cash acquired) for the acquisitions of PSSI, Summit, Service Works, the assets of the BWI security operation of Akal, SEB and Platt. Additionally, we received a $1.4 million refund from escrow and recorded a measurement period adjustment of $1.4 million to cash and restricted cash acquired as part of the acquisition of SOS. For the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, we paid $46.7 million and $47.9 million, respectively, for purchases of property and equipment and paid $9.2 million and $2.2 million, respectively, for purchases of marketable securities. Proceeds from the sale of property and equipment were $2.7 million and $1.7 million for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. During the year ended December 31, 2019, we paid approximately $762.6 million (net of cash acquired) for the acquisitions of Securadyne, Point 2 Point, Cypress, Shetler, Midstate, Advent, Vinson, APG and SOS, received a $10.0 million refund from escrow related to a USSA acquisition working capital adjustment and received a $1.7 million refund from escrow related to the settlement of certain Covenant acquisition earn out provisions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financing activities have consisted primarily of borrowings and repayments on long-term debt associated with acquisitions of businesses. Cash provided by financing activities for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 was $451.1 million and $759.7 million, respectively.
