ORGANIZATION OF THE COMPANY Allied Universal Holdco LLC (“Holdco”) conducts all its operations through its wholly-owned subsidiaries, including, Allied Universal Sideco LLC (“Sideco”), Universal Services of America, LP (“USA LP”) and USA LP’s wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries (collectively, the “Company”). Holdco is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Allied Universal Topco LLC (“Topco”). The Company provides security officer, or manned guarding, services, including specialized security officer services such as vehicle patrol, visitor management, executive protection, K-9 security services, secret and top secret cleared security professionals. In addition, the Company provides comprehensive technology solutions, including video surveillance, closed circuit television (“CCTV”) picture capture and monitoring, robot patrolling, GPS-based patrol and reporting, management of access control points and centralized security operations. The Company offers systems integration services to design, install and service fully-integrated technology-based monitoring systems, along with digital solutions and remote monitoring. The Company also offers ancillary services, including temporary and permanent staffing, event staffing and security, janitorial services, and consulting and investigation solutions. The Company, which was founded in 1965, is co-located in Santa Ana, CA and Conshohocken, PA, and conducts its operations principally through offices across the United States of America and Puerto Rico and has operations in Canada, Latin America and the United Kingdom. On May 2, 2016, Holdco and Topco entered into an Agreement and Plan of Merger Agreement (the “Allied Agreement”) with Vigilant Holdings LP (“Vigilant”), then parent company of Allied Security Holdings LLC and its subsidiaries (collectively, “Allied”) and an indirect subsidiary of Wendel SE, a European investment firm (the “Allied Transaction”). The closing of the Allied Transaction occurred on August 1, 2016 (“Closing Date”), at which time Vigilant was merged into Holdco with Holdco surviving. As a consequence of the Allied Transaction, Warburg Pincus LLC and Wendel SE held equal ownership interests in Topco, with Partners Group and certain members of Company management also holding ownership interests. On February 20, 2019, the Company announced that Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec (“CDPQ”), a Canadian institutional investor, agreed to make an investment in Topco, including $208.0 million of primary capital, which was contributed to Holdco. On September 18, 2019, Wendel SE announced that it had reached an agreement with CDPQ and other holders of existing ownership interests in Topco to sell part of its ownership interest in Topco to a new investment group led by Warburg Pincus LLC and an affiliate of the J. Safra Group. These transactions (collectively, the “CDPQ Transaction”) closed on December 12, 2019. Funds exchanged for ownership interest in Topco that occurred at the investor level are not reflected within these consolidated financial statements. As a consequence of the CDPQ Transaction, while CDPQ holds a significant but non-controlling ownership interest in Topco, the new investment group led by Warburg Pincus LLC maintains a controlling interest in Topco, with certain members of Company management also holding ownership interests. On April 29, 2020, Wendel SE sold its remaining ownership interest in Topco to the new investment group led by Warburg Pincus LLC. ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) 2. BASIS OF PRESENTATION AND SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES Principles of Consolidation—The Company’s consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“GAAP”). The Company’s consolidated financial statements present the financial position, results of operations, and cash flows of the Company and its wholly and majority-owned subsidiaries. Intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated in consolidation. Results of operations of businesses acquired are included from their respective dates of acquisition. The Company records the impact of its minority member’s interests in one of its subsidiaries as a non- controlling interest. The non-controlling interest is presented in the consolidated statements of operations and the consolidated statements of comprehensive loss as an increase or reduction to net income or loss to arrive at the net income or loss attributable to the Company. The non-controlling interest is also shown as a separate line item in member’s capital in the consolidated balance sheets. Certain amounts in the consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2019 and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2019 have been reclassified to conform to the current period presentation. These reclassifications had no effect on the Company’s previously reported financial position, results of operations or cash flows. Estimates—Management has made estimates and assumptions that affect the reported assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent liabilities, and reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019. Actual results could differ from those estimates. COVID-19—The Company continues to closely monitor developments related to the novel coronavirus (“COVID-19”) pandemic to assess any potential impact on its business. The extent of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the Company’s operational and financial performance will depend, in large part, on the effect on its workforce, clients and vendors, all of which are uncertain at this time and cannot be predicted. In March and early April 2020, the Company experienced a mid-single digit percent reduction in billable service hours from its pre-COVID-19 period of January and February. However, hours stabilized beginning in late April, with hours increasing such that by the fourth quarter of 2020, hours were closer to January and February levels, but hours remained slightly down compared to 2019. The Company has also seen growth in margins, particularly during the second and third quarters of 2020, which offset the impact of the loss of hours, mainly as a result of an increase in premium services, lower overtime, reduced security professional turnover and reduced travel. Additionally, during March 2020, the Company borrowed $500.0 million under the ABL Credit Facility out of an abundance of caution in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. After not using any of the additional cash provided by this borrowing, the Company repaid the $500.0 million in full during August 2020. While the Company currently does not anticipate that the COVID-19 pandemic will have a materially adverse impact on its business, as a result of the evolving and highly uncertain nature of the COVID-19 pandemic, no assurance may be made regarding potential exposure or the indirect effects of the outbreak on the Company’s business, results of operations, cash flows, liquidity and financial condition. On March 27, 2020, the U.S government enacted the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (the “CARES Act”). The CARES Act is an emergency economic stimulus package in response to the COVID-19 pandemic which, among other things, contains numerous income tax provisions. The CARES Act allows the Company to defer the payment of the employer share of social security taxes for ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) the period beginning March 27, 2020 through December 31, 2020. Based on the CARES Act, the Company deferred $282.0 million of qualified payroll tax payments as of December 31, 2020, of which, $141.0 million is recorded within accrued payroll and related taxes and $141.0 million is recorded within other liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet. The current portion of this liability is due by December 31, 2021 with the remainder due by December 31, 2022. Additionally, the Company was able to deduct additional Section 163(j) interest carryforward amounts as a result of the increase in the limitation provided by the CARES Act. The Company will continue to monitor future guidance issued regarding the CARES Act to determine any future impacts. On December 27, 2020, The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021 (“CAA”) was signed into law. The CAA clarifies and expands the Paycheck Protection Program loans and the Employee Retention Credit as well as several other tax provisions first outlined in the CARES Act. The CAA is currently being evaluated, however, the Company does not anticipate a material impact as a result of this legislation. Revenue Recognition—In accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers, the Company accounts for a customer contract when both parties have approved the arrangement, the performance obligations can be identified, payment terms can be determined and it is probable the Company will collect substantially all of the consideration to which it is entitled. The Company recognizes revenue when its performance obligation is satisfied upon the transfer of control of the promised product or service to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for those goods and services. Revenue is recognized over time in the period in which services are provided pursuant to the terms of the Company's contractual relationships with its clients. The Company primarily accounts for its performance obligation under the series guidance and applies the invoice practical expedient to record revenue as services are provided, given the nature of the services provided and the frequency of billing under the customer contracts. By applying the invoice practical expedient, the Company recognizes revenue in an amount that corresponds directly with the value to the customer of the Company’s performance completed to date and for which the Company has the right to invoice the customer. The Company generally bills its customers either in advance, weekly, bi-weekly or monthly. Manned guarding service revenue is generally measured based on the billable hours served by security officers and the rate per billable hour, as determined by the underlying customer contract. Janitorial and other ancillary service revenue is recognized in the month services are performed. Advance payments of $9.2 million and $9.3 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, represent amounts received from customers in advance of performing the related services and are included in accrued expenses and other current liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets. The underlying revenue is recognized when the Company performs the related service. Unbilled services rendered represent revenue that has been earned, but has not yet been invoiced. The Company reports revenue net of sales tax collected from customers that are then remitted to government taxing authorities. Taxes collected are recorded as current liabilities until remitted to the applicable government taxing authority. Revenues from video and alarm monitoring and security systems service and installation contracts are recorded as control is transferred to the Company’s clients over time, as any assets created or enhanced by the Company’s performance are controlled by the Company’s clients, there are no alternative uses for any assets created, and the Company has a legally enforceable right to payment for performance completed. Revenue is recognized using the cost-to-cost input method, which measures the percentage of total cost incurred to date to the estimated total cost for each contract. As of December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company recorded $9.7 million and $13.2 million, respectively, in prepaid and other current ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) assets for costs and estimated earnings in excess of billings on contracts-in-progress and $9.4 million and $6.4 million, respectively, in accrued expenses and other current liabilities for billings in excess of costs and estimated earnings on contracts-in-progress. Restricted Cash—The Company has balances on deposit with the Company’s insurance carriers to pay workers’ compensation claims and general liability insurance claims as they become due and an account designated for the benefit of employees, which is reserved expressly for non-comingled uniform deposit funds. Amounts in these accounts are reflected as restricted cash in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. Accounts Receivable, Net of Allowance for Doubtful Accounts—Accounts receivable, net are carried at their estimated collectible amounts. The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of its customers to make required payments. The Company has recorded allowances in the amount of $34.6 million and $26.0 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Management considers the following factors when determining the collectability of specific customer accounts: (1) customer creditworthiness, (2) aging of accounts receivable, (3) past transaction history with the customer, (4) current economic industry trends and (5) changes in customer payment terms. If the financial condition of the Company’s customers were to deteriorate, adversely affecting their ability to make payments, the Company would provide additional allowances. Based on management’s assessment, the Company provides for estimated uncollectible amounts through a charge to earnings and a credit to the allowance for doubtful accounts. Balances that remain outstanding after the Company has used reasonable collection efforts are written off through a charge to the allowance for doubtful accounts and a reduction to customer accounts receivable. Inventories—Inventories consist principally of purchased parts of security equipment for installation and is stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value. Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out (“FIFO”) method. Inventories amounted to $3.7 million and $3.0 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, and are included in prepaid and other current assets in the consolidated balance sheets. Income Taxes—The majority of the Company is treated as a partnership for federal and state income tax purposes. As a result, its members report their share of the Company’s income or loss which has been allocated to the members under the respective membership agreements between Holdco and its subsidiaries or among its subsidiaries on their respective income tax returns. The membership agreements of the Company have provisions requiring the distribution of funds to the members in amounts sufficient for the members to satisfy their federal, state, and local tax obligations with respect to their share of Company income, subject to board approval. Within the Company’s financial reporting structure, several of the operating or holding company entities are treated as corporations for federal and state income tax purposes. The consolidated financial statements reflect a tax provision or benefit for the income taxes associated with these entities and deferred income tax assets and liabilities, where appropriate, related to differences between the accounting and tax treatment of items related to these entities. Where, based on the weight of available evidence, it is more likely than not that some amount of a recorded deferred tax asset will not be realized, a valuation allowance is established for the amount sufficient to reduce that deferred tax asset to an amount that is more likely than not to be realized. ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) Under the terms of the various membership agreements between entities within the Company’s financial reporting structure, the allocation of profits or losses from operating entities to the corporate members varies based on the results of operations for the year. Amounts allocated to corporate members could be material in any given year and result in material amounts of current or deferred income tax expense or benefit to be reported in the accompanying consolidated financial statements. The Company’s consolidated financial statements reflect a tax provision for these corporate taxes plus taxes imposed on the Company’s operating entities which are primarily minimum tax payments plus fees based on the annual gross receipts of the particular reporting entity. Property and Equipment—Property and equipment, including assets under capital lease, are recorded at cost and are depreciated using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of each asset. Leasehold improvements are recorded at cost and amortized using the straight-line method over the shorter of the term of the lease or the estimated useful life. In accordance with ASC Topic 360, Property, Plant, and Equipment, the Company reviews its long- lived assets for impairment on an ongoing basis and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable. Recoverability of these assets is determined based upon the expected undiscounted future net cash flows from the operations to which the assets relate, utilizing management’s best estimates, appropriate assumptions, and projections at the time of review. If the carrying value is determined not to be recoverable from future operating cash flows, the asset is deemed impaired, and an impairment loss would be recognized to the extent the carrying value exceeded the estimated fair market value of the asset. No impairment was identified or recorded for the years ended December 31, 2020 or 2019. Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets—The Company records goodwill as the excess of the purchase price of an acquired entity over the net of the fair values assigned to identifiable tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed. In accordance with ASC Topic 350, Intangibles—Goodwill and Other, the Company tests its goodwill for impairment annually at October 1. The Company evaluates the recoverability of goodwill based on an assessment of qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of its single reporting unit is less than its carrying amount. In the qualitative assessment, the Company considers the macroeconomic conditions, including any deterioration of general conditions and industry and market conditions, changes in the products/services and regulatory and political developments, cost of doing business, overall financial performance, including any declining cash flows and performance in relation to planned revenues and earnings in past periods, other relevant reporting unit specific facts, such as changes in management or key personnel or pending litigation, and events affecting the reporting unit, including changes in the carrying value of net assets. If the Company determines that it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying value, then the Company would perform the quantitative goodwill impairment test as required. If the Company determines that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying value, then no further testing is required. If the carrying amount exceeds the fair value then the Company would record an impairment loss in an amount equal to that excess, limited to the total amount of goodwill recorded. The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting unit based on a combination of significant observable and unobservable inputs, including estimates of future operating performance. Changes in market conditions, among other factors, may have an impact on these estimates. During the year ended December 31, 2020, the Company performed a qualitative assessment and determined that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of the ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) reporting unit is less than its carrying value. There were no impairment charges recorded during the years ended December 31, 2020 or 2019. The Company’s trade names have been determined to be indefinite-lived identifiable intangible assets and therefore are not amortized. The Company’s finite-lived identifiable intangible assets, such as customer contracts, non-compete agreements and technology are amortized over their estimated economic lives on a straight-line basis. Intangible assets are tested for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable. For our indefinite- lived trade names, the Company also conducts an assessment of qualitative factors to determine whether or not it is more likely than not that the fair value of the assets is less than their carrying value. If the Company determines that it is more likely than not that the fair value of the trade names is less than their carrying value, the Company estimates the fair value of its indefinite-lived trade names using the relief from royalty method. The relief from royalty method measures the discounted cash flow savings realized from owning such intangible assets and not having to pay a royalty for their use. Impairment would then be recognized for the difference between the determined fair value and their carrying value, if applicable. Management performs the trade name impairment test annually at October 1, regardless of the results of the goodwill evaluation. During the year ended December 31, 2020, the Company performed a qualitative assessment and determined that it is not more likely than not that the fair values of indefinite-lived trade names are less than their carrying values. There were no impairment charges recorded during the years ended December 31, 2020 or 2019. Marketable Securities—The Company’s investments in marketable securities are carried at fair value based on quoted market prices. Unrealized gains and losses are included in earnings and are reported in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations as a component of interest expense, net. All of the Company’s marketable securities are classified as long-term because they support the long-term Supplemental Income Plan (“SIP”) liability and long-term deferred compensation plan liability assumed as part of the acquisition of U.S. Security Associates, Inc. (“USSA”) and include investments that do not have contractual maturities due to the nature of the investment vehicles. Marketable securities consist principally of mutual funds invested in United States of America equity securities, government securities and money market funds. Unrealized gains on marketable securities for the year ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 were $4.3 million and $5.0 million, respectively. The estimated fair values of the Company’s marketable securities are $51.4 million and $37.9 million at December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, and are included with deposits and other long-term assets in the consolidated balance sheets. Concentrations of Credit Risk—Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk include cash and trade accounts receivable that are not collateralized. Concentrations of credit risk with respect to trade receivables are limited since the Company’s revenue base is composed of a large number of customers that are dispersed across different industries and geographic areas. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, no customer represented greater than 10.0% of total accounts receivable or revenue. Cash accounts at each financial institution are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation up to $250 thousand. The Company routinely maintains cash at several financial institutions in excess of insured limits. The Company has not experienced any losses in such accounts and management believes it is not exposed to any significant credit risk on cash. ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) Fair Value Measurements—The Company applies fair value accounting for all financial assets and liabilities that are recognized or disclosed at fair value in the consolidated financial statements. The Company determines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. The Company utilizes valuation techniques that maximize the use of observable inputs (Levels 1 and 2) and minimize the use of unobservable inputs (Level 3) within the fair value hierarchy established by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (“FASB”). The Company applies both a market approach and income approach to determine fair value. The market approach uses pricing and other information generated by market transactions for identical or comparable assets and liabilities. The income approach seeks to identify future cash flows to be generated and compare them with a required rate of return. Assets and liabilities are classified within the fair value hierarchy based on the lowest level (least observable) input that is significant to the measurement in its entirety. The estimated fair value of financial instruments has been determined based on management’s assessment of available market information and appropriate valuation methodologies. The carrying value of short-term financial instruments, such as cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and various accrued expenses, approximates their fair value based on the short-term maturities of these instruments. The estimated fair value of marketable securities at December 31, 2020 and 2019 was $51.4 million and $37.9 million, respectively, based on quoted market prices (Level 1). The estimated fair values of the Company’s debt instruments are estimated using current market pricing quotes (Level 2). At December 31, 2020, the estimated fair values of the Company’s first lien term loan, senior secured notes and senior unsecured notes are approximately $2,187.4 million, $2,070.5 million and $1,142.0 million, respectively, as compared to their carrying values, exclusive of discounts, premiums and related fees, of $2,197.8 million, $1,940.0 million and $1,050.0 million, respectively. At December 31, 2019, the estimated fair values of the Company’s first lien term loan, senior secured notes and senior unsecured notes were approximately $2,241.2 million, $1,075.6 million and $1,126.2 million, respectively, as compared to their carrying values, exclusive of discounts and related fees, of $2,220.0 million, $1,000.0 million and $1,050.0 million, respectively. Insurance Reserves—The Company maintains insurance coverage, subject to certain self-insured retention limits, for workers’ compensation, general liability, employment practices liability, automobile liability and healthcare claims. Medical benefit costs for the majority of the Company’s workforce are premium-based. Costs associated with the premium-based plans equal the actual premiums paid and premiums can fluctuate. Conversely, for administrative employees and security officers not subject to premium-based coverage, the Company is self-insured and subject to self-insured retention limits. The Company records its reserves for workers’ compensation, general liability, employment practices liability and automobile liability based on a third-party actuarial analysis which includes amounts adequate to cover the ultimate claim, incurred but not reported development risk and litigation defense costs. Estimates of the ultimate cost of claims are derived from the level of the Company’s insurance coverage and the Company’s retained risk of loss. The Company records a reserve for healthcare claims based upon a third-party lag study analysis. Management reviews these estimates on a quarterly basis subject to information then currently available to assess their adequacy and the propriety of disclosure. The Company adjusts the reserves, if needed, based on the results of management’s review. Assessing ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) the adequacy of these reserves is highly subjective and requires judgments about future events. The amount of the actual loss may differ significantly from these estimates. Leases—The Company’s facilities and certain vehicles, equipment, and uniforms are leased and accounted for under the provisions of ASC Topic 840, Leases, and subsequent amendments, which require that leases be evaluated and classified as operating or capital leases for financial reporting purposes. The lease term begins when the Company has the right to control the use of the property, which is typically before rent payments are due under the lease agreement. Certain facility leases contain rent escalation clauses, which are recorded on a straight-line basis over the initial term of the lease with the difference between actual rent payments and the straight-line rent expense recorded as a deferred rent liability. In addition, the Company has financed certain uniforms and vehicles through capital lease arrangements and has assumed capital lease obligations. The current portion of capital lease obligations is included in long-term debt and capital lease obligations, current portion, and the non-current portion of capital lease obligations is included in long-term debt and capital lease obligations, net of current portion, in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. Capitalized lease assets are amortized over the shorter of the economic useful life of the asset or the lease term. Purchase Price Payable—As part of certain completed acquisitions, the Company has agreed to pay cash to the sellers based upon achievement of certain targets after the acquisition date. The Company evaluates the fair value of contingent consideration throughout the year and every reporting period. Changes in the fair value during the measurement period that pertain to facts and circumstances that existed as of the acquisition date are recorded as measurement period adjustments to goodwill. Changes in the fair value resulting from events that occurred after the acquisition date are recorded as a gain or loss on changes in fair value of the contingent purchase consideration in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations. As of December 31, 2020 and 2019, $16.3 million and $30.5 million, respectively, is reported in accrued expenses and other current liabilities and $0 and $7.1 million, respectively, is reported in other liabilities for purchase price payable. Member’s Equity Unit-Based Compensation—The Company’s management incentive plans allow the Company to attract and retain employees by allowing them to retain an equity interest in and participate in the long-term growth and financial success of the Company. The Company accounts for its equity unit-based compensation in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 718, Compensation-Stock Compensation. Under ASC Topic 718, equity unit-based compensation costs are measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the equity award and are recognized in the statements of operations over the period during which an employee is required to provide service in exchange for the award. The Company determines the grant-date fair value of equity unit awards using an appropriate option-pricing method. The Company recognizes the equity unit-based compensation expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period of the award and presents such expense as a separate line item under operating costs and expenses in the consolidated statements of operations. The Company uses an independent valuation advisor to assist with determining equity unit valuations for calculating equity unit-based compensation. The Company considers both the historical volatility of its peer group’s stock price, as well as implied volatilities from exchange-traded options on its peer group’s equity units, as applicable. The expected term used by the Company represents the period that the Company’s equity units are expected to be outstanding and is determined using the simplified method described in ASC Topic 718-10-30. The assumptions used in calculating the fair value of equity unit-based awards represent management’s best estimates, but these estimates involve inherent ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) uncertainties and the application of management’s judgment. As a result, if factors change and the Company uses different assumptions, equity unit-based compensation could materially differ in the future. New Accounting Pronouncements—Accounting Standards Update (“ASU”) No. 2016-02, Leases (“ASU 2016-02”), was issued in February 2016. ASU 2016-02 provides for a comprehensive change to lease accounting. The new standard requires that a lessee recognize a lease obligation liability and a right to use an asset for virtually all leases of property, plant, and equipment, subsequently amortized over the lease term. In July 2018, the FASB issued ASU No. 2018-11, Leases: Targeted Improvements, (“ASU 2018-11”), which allows entities the option to adopt this standard prospectively with a cumulative-effect adjustment to opening equity and include required disclosures for prior periods. In November 2019, the FASB issued ASU No. 2019-10, Effective Dates, (“ASU 2019-10”), which amended the effective date of ASU 2016-02 and related amendments. In June 2020, the FASB issued ASU 2020-05 to provide nonpublic entities with an option to defer the adoption of ASC Topic 842, Leases, from annual periods beginning after December 15, 2020 to annual periods beginning after December 15, 2021 and interim periods within fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022. The Company has elected this optional deferral period. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of ASU 2016-02 and related amendments on its consolidated financial statement disclosures, results of operations, financial position and cash flows. While the Company has not yet determined the ultimate impact, it anticipates that ASU 2016-02 and related amendments will have a material impact on its financial position by increasing the Company’s assets and liabilities through the recognition of right-of- use assets and lease liabilities for its operating leases. ASU No. 2016-13, Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments (“ASU 2016-13”), was issued in June 2016 to provide financial statement users with more decision-useful information about the expected credit losses on financial instruments and other commitments to extend credit held by a reporting entity at each reporting date. The amendments in ASU 2016-13 replace the incurred loss impairment methodology with a methodology that reflects expected credit losses and requires consideration of a broader range of reasonable and supportable information to inform credit loss estimates. ASU 2016-13 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022, and interim periods therein. While the Company is currently evaluating the impact of ASU 2016-13, the adoption is not expected to have a material impact on its results of operations, financial position or cash flows. ASU No. 2017-04, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Simplifying the Accounting for Goodwill Impairment (“ASU 2017-04”), was issued in January 2017. ASU 2017-04 simplifies the subsequent measurement of goodwill by eliminating Step 2 from the goodwill impairment test. The goodwill impairment test is performed by comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount. An impairment charge should be recognized for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit’s fair value; however, the loss recognized should not exceed the total amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit. In addition, income tax effects from any tax-deductible goodwill on the carrying amount of the reporting unit should be considered when measuring the goodwill impairment loss, if applicable. ASU 2017-04 also eliminates the requirement for any reporting unit with a zero or negative carrying amount to perform a qualitative assessment. ASU 2017-04 should be applied on a prospective basis. In November 2019, the FASB issued ASU 2019-10, which amended the effective date of ASU 2017-04. ASU 2017-04 is effective for annual or any interim goodwill impairment tests in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022. Early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017. The ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) Company adopted the provisions of ASU 2017-04 during the year ended December 31, 2020, and it did not have a material impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statement disclosures, results of operations or financial position. ASU No. 2018-07, Compensation-Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Nonemployee Share-Based Payment Accounting (“ASU 2018-07”), was issued in June 2018 and supersedes the guidance in Subtopic 505-50, Equity-Equity-Based Payments to Non-Employees. In particular, ASU 2018-07 expands the scope of topic 718, Compensation-Stock Compensation (which previously only included payments to employees), to include share-based payment transactions for acquiring goods and services from non-employees. An entity should now apply the requirements of Topic 718 to non- employee awards, except for specific guidance on inputs to an option pricing model and the attribution of cost (i.e., the period of time over which share-based payment awards vest and the pattern of cost recognition over that period). Additionally, the amendments specify that Topic 718 applies to all share- based payment transactions in which a grantor acquires goods or services to be used or consumed in the grantor’s own operations by issuing share-based payment awards, and clarify that Topic 718 does not apply to share-based payments used to effectively provide (1) financing to the issuer, or (2) awards granted in conjunction with selling goods or services to customers as part of a contract accounted for under Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers. The amendments are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, and for interim periods with fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020. The Company adopted the provisions of ASU 2018-07 during the year ended December 31, 2020 and it did not have a material impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statement disclosures, results of operations, financial position or cash flows. ASU No. 2018-13, Fair Value Measurement (Topic 820): Disclosure Framework-Changes to the Disclosure Requirements for Fair Value Measurement (“ASU 2018-13”), was issued in August 2018 and modifies the disclosure requirements for fair value measurements in Topic 820, Fair Value Measurement. Specifically, the amendments remove disclosure requirements in Topic 820 related to (1) the amount of, and reasons for, transfers between Level 1 and Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy; (2) the policy for timing of transfers between levels; (3) the valuation processes for Level 3 fair value measurements. The amendments are effective for fiscal years, and for interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2019. Early adoption is permitted. The Company adopted the provisions of ASU 2018-13 during the year ended December 31, 2020 and it did not have a material impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statement disclosures, results of operations or financial position. ASU No. 2018-15, Intangibles-Goodwill and Other-Internal-Use Software (Subtopic 350-40): Customer’s Accounting for Implementation Costs Incurred in a Cloud Computing Arrangement That Is a Service Contract (“ASU 2018-15”), was issued in August 2018 and requires implementation costs incurred by customers in cloud computing arrangements to be deferred and recognized over the term of the arrangement, if those costs would be capitalized by the customer in a software licensing arrangement under the internal-use software guidance in ASC Topic 350, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other. ASU 2018-15 requires a customer to disclose the nature of its hosting arrangements that are service contracts and provide disclosures as if the deferred implementation costs were a separate, major depreciable asset class. ASU 2018-15 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2020. Early adoption is permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of ASU 2018-15 on its consolidated financial statement disclosures, results of operations and financial position. ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) ASU No. 2019-12, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Simplifying the Accounting for Income Taxes (“ASU 2019-12”) was issued in December 2019 and simplifies the accounting for income taxes, eliminates certain exceptions within ASC Topic 740, Income Taxes, and clarifies certain aspects of the current guidance to promote consistency among reporting entities. ASU 2019-12 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021 and interim periods within fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of ASU 2019-12 on its consolidated financial statement disclosures, results of operations, financial position and cash flows. ASU No. 2020-04, (Topic 848): Facilitation of the Effects of Reference Rate Reform on Financial Reporting (“ASU 2020-04”), was issued in March 2020 to provide optional expedients and exceptions for applying GAAP to contracts, hedging relationships and other transactions affected by reference rate reform. ASU 2020-04 is elective and applies to all entities, subject to meeting certain criteria, that have contracts, hedging relationships, and other transactions that reference the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) or another reference rate expected to be discontinued because of reference rate reform. ASU 2020-04 was subject to election as of March 20, 2020 and can be elected for both interim and annual periods through December 31, 2022. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of ASU 2020-04 on its consolidated results of operations, financial position and cash flows. 3. Business Insurance Risks (Workers’ Compensation, General Liability, Employment Practices Liability, Automobile Liability and certain Healthcare Claims) and Tax Assessment Risk In the normal course of operations, various legal claims are filed against the Company for which the Company maintains insurance coverage. The Company has established reserves for these claims based on insurance coverage, the risk of loss retained by the Company and management's judgment. Management does not expect the ultimate outcome of any of these actions to have a material adverse effect on the Company’s consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flows. The Company maintains insurance coverage, subject to certain self-insured retentions, for workers’ compensation, general liability, employment practices liability, automobile liability and certain healthcare claims. The Company reserves for all known claims and those claims that management believes have been “incurred but not reported” as of the balance sheet date based on its estimate of the ultimate cost of the claims. Management derives the estimated ultimate cost of claims from the level of the Company’s insurance coverage, its retained risk of loss, historical trends and judgment. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, the accrued provision for estimated claims, excluding certain healthcare claims was $351.7 million and $314.8 million, respectively, of which $96.9 million and $90.6 million, respectively, is included in accrued claims reserves, current portion and $254.8 million and $224.2 million, respectively, is included in accrued claims reserves, net of current portion within long- term liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. On October 21, 2020, Security Casualty Risk Retention Group, Inc. (the “RRG”) was created and incorporated in the state of South Carolina. The RRG is designed to provide an alternative to the historical commercial insurance coverage for general liability and is directly or indirectly owned by the subsidiaries of the Company, all of which are also policy holders. The RRG is effective for selected claims originating as of and subsequent to January 1, 2021, and therefore, the RRG has no impact on the consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020. ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) In the normal course of business, the Company is audited by taxing authorities and from time to time, receives proposed tax assessments as a result of those audits. The Company records obligations for those proposed tax assessments or portion thereof that management believes are probable of payment and estimable. Management believes that even if any one or more proposed assessment resulted in an unfavorable outcome, they would not be material to the Company’s financial position individually or in the aggregate. The timing and outcome of a settlement of any proposed assessment may not always be reasonably ascertained. 9. RETIREMENT PLANS a) Defined Contribution Plans The Company has 401(k) plans covering substantially all of its employees. The Company may make discretionary matching contributions to qualified participants. Matching contributions for qualified participants amounted to $5.1 million and $2.4 million for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. b) Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan The Company maintains a non-qualified Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (“SERP”) for certain senior executives of the Company. Effective August 1, 2016, all further annual plan awards were discontinued. The SERP contains a notional account for each participant that is increased annually for interest earned. All current participants are fully vested in their respective notional accounts. The Board of Managers oversees and administers the SERP and is responsible for determining the rate of annual earnings on the notional accounts (currently 4%). The Company’s expense related to the SERP was $0.2 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company included $5.2 million and $5.0 million, respectively, in other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets for its obligation under the SERP. c) Supplemental Income Plan The Company sponsors a non-qualified SIP for a select group of management employees who are not eligible to participate in the Company’s qualified 401(k) plans. The Company has segregated assets in the marketable securities account of $32.5 million and $24.0 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, which it intends to utilize to fund this liability. Employee vesting occurs over six years of service beginning after completion of two years with the Company. The Company had expense related to the SIP of $5.8 million and $5.0 million for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company included $34.4 million and $25.7 million, respectively, in other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets for its obligation under the SIP. d) Deferred Compensation Plan As a result of the acquisition of USSA, the Company sponsors a deferred compensation plan for certain previous employees of USSA. The plan is frozen for any new contributions or enrollment as of December 31, 2018. The Company has segregated assets in the marketable securities account of $18.9 ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) million and $13.9 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, which it intends to utilize to fund this liability. The Company’s expense related to the deferred compensation plan was $2.0 million and $2.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company included $20.5 million and $19.0 million, respectively, in other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets for its obligation under the plan. 10. COMPENSATION MATTERS Equity awards issued in conjunction with the Allied Transaction Allied Continuing Class B Units In conjunction with the Allied Transaction, all partnership units in Vigilant were replaced with membership units in Topco (the “Allied Continuing Class B Units”). Immediately prior to the CDPQ Transaction, the Company had 3,757,940 Allied Continuing Class B Units outstanding. During the year ended December 31, 2019, no Allied Continuing Class B Units were issued or forfeited due to terminations of employment. In connection with the CDPQ Transaction, all of the Allied Continuing Class B Units were accelerated and settled. ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) Key Terms of the Allied Continuing Class B Units In conjunction with the Allied Transaction, 40% of the Allied Continuing Class B Units issued were fully vested on the Closing Date, while the other 60% of the Allied Continuing Class B Units were subject to certain change in control provisions whereby unvested awards may vest upon a triggering event, subject to internal rate of return (“IRR”) targets and the award holder’s continued provision of services through the consummation of such triggering event. During the year ended December 31, 2019, due to all of the Allied Continuing Class B Units being accelerated and settled, the Company recognized $0.1 million of equity unit-based compensation expense, which represents the total compensation cost related to the Allied Continuing Class B Units that had not been previously recognized. Topco New Class B Units In conjunction with the Allied Transaction, Topco entered into Class B Unit Letter Award agreements (the “2016 Incentive Plan”) with certain management-level employees of the merged Company (the “Topco New Class B Units”). As of January 1, 2019, the Company had 102,327,710 Topco New Class B Units outstanding. During the year ended December 31, 2019, no additional Topco New Class B Units were issued and 472,824 Topco New Class B Units were forfeited due to terminations of employment. In connection with the CDPQ Transaction, all of the Topco New Class B Units were accelerated and settled. All holders of the Topco New Class B Units were current employees of the Company at the time of the CDPQ Transaction. With respect to each Topco New Class B Unit Award, the effective date of each agreement was the date on which a board decision was received. Key Terms of the 2016 Incentive Plan Pursuant to the 2016 Incentive Plan, 50% of the Topco New Class B Units issued were subject to time- vesting and 50% of the Topco New Class B Units vested subject to certain change in control provisions whereby unvested units may vest upon a triggering event, subject to IRR targets and each unit holder’s continued provision of services through the consummation of such triggering event. Topco New Class B Units granted to existing management members subject to time-vesting began on the grant date with 60% of the units vested immediately and the remaining 40% of the units vested ratably in annual installments over the four-year period following the Closing Date, such that, by the fourth anniversary of the Closing Date, 100% of the time-based units would be vested. For new employees, time-based Topco New Class B Units vested in ratable annual installments over the four-year period following the grant date, such that, by the fourth anniversary of the grant date, 100% of the time-based units would be fully vested. Topco New Class B Units that were subject to performance conditions, whether granted to existing employees or new employees, vested solely on achievement of IRR targets (as defined in the 2016 ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) Incentive Plan), with 0% of the performance-based Topco New Class B Units vesting at IRR of 15% and 100% of the performance-based Topco New Class B Units vesting at IRR of 20%, with the vested percentage on IRR between 15% and 20% to be determined by linear interpolation. Equity unit-based compensation expense recognized on Topco New Class B Units for the year ended December 31, 2019 was $5.0 million, based on the satisfaction of time and performance conditions and the acceleration of the compensation cost in connection with the CDPQ Transaction. Equity awards issued in conjunction with the CDPQ Transaction Topco New Incentive Units In conjunction with the CDPQ Transaction, Topco entered into Incentive Units Award Letter agreements (the “2019 Incentive Plan”) with certain management-level employees of the Company (the “Topco New Incentive Units”). (210,463) $     (300,031) #### On March 27, 2020, the U.S government enacted the CARES Act. The CARES Act is an emergency economic stimulus package in response to the COVID-19 pandemic which, among other things, contains numerous income tax provisions. The CARES Act allows the Company to defer the payment of the employer share of social security taxes for the period beginning March 27, 2020 through December 31, 2020. Based on the CARES Act, the Company deferred $282.0 million of qualified payroll tax payments as of December 31, 2020, of which, $141.0 million is recorded within accrued payroll and related taxes and $141.0 million is recorded within other liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet. The current portion of this liability is due by December 31, 2021 with the remainder due by December 31, 2022. Additionally, the Company was able to deduct additional Section 163(j) interest carryforward amounts as a result of the increase in the limitation provided by the CARES Act. The Company will continue to monitor future guidance issued regarding the CARES Act to determine any future impacts. On December 27, 2020, The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021 (“CAA”) was signed into law. The CAA clarifies and expands the Paycheck Protection Program loans and the Employee Retention Credit as well as several other tax provisions first outlined in the CARES Act. The CAA is currently being evaluated, however, the Company does not anticipate a material impact as a result of this legislation. The Company’s largest deferred tax liability relates to amounts ascribed to the value of stock in corporate subsidiaries where the underlying assets and liabilities of the corporation (primarily, partnership interests holding intangible assets, including goodwill) have been revalued under GAAP but not for tax purposes. The remaining deferred tax liability substantially relates to the difference in fair value and net tax value of intangibles created when the Company acquired USSA and SOS (See Note 10). ----- #### NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS OF AND FOR THE YEARS ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 AND 2019 (DOLLARS IN THOUSANDS, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE STATED) Operating Loss and Tax Credit Carryforwards At December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company’s operating subsidiaries had net operating loss carry- forwards of approximately $43.1 million and $24.8 million, respectively, in various jurisdictions. The Company’s net operating loss carryforwards do not expire. The Company also has tax credit carry- forwards available to offset future tax liabilities of approximately $14.4 million and $16.4 million at December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, which have various expiration dates but begin to expire in 2035. Valuation Allowance Where, based on the weight of available evidence, it is more likely than not that some amount of a recorded deferred tax asset will not be realized, a valuation allowance is established for the amount sufficient to reduce that deferred tax asset to an amount that will more likely than not be realized. Management believes that future results will be sufficient to realize the Company’s deferred tax assets with the exception of certain foreign tax credits (“FTC”) which were generated pre-acquisition by USSA. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, a valuation allowance of $0.9 million and $1.3 million, respectively, has been established against federal deferred tax assets related to these FTCs. Based on available evidence, including management projections, the Company does not expect to be able to utilize the FTCs in future years. Uncertain Tax Positions The Company files U.S. federal, state, and foreign tax returns. The Company strives to resolve open matters with each tax authority at the examination level and could reach agreement with a tax authority at any time. While the Company has accrued for amounts it believes are in accordance with the accounting standard, the final outcome with a tax authority may result in a tax liability that is more or less than that reflected in the consolidated financial statements. Tax returns for years beginning in 2016 are subject to audit by the Internal Revenue Service and various tax authorities. Furthermore, the Company may later decide to challenge any assessments, if made, and may exercise its right to appeal. Uncertain tax positions are reviewed annually with guidance provided in ASC 740 for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return that directly or indirectly affect amounts reported in financial statements. ASC 740 also provides accounting guidance for the related income tax effects of individual tax positions that do not meet the recognition thresholds required in order for any part of the benefit of that tax position to be recognized in an entity’s financial statements. At December 31, 2020 and 2019, a total of $0 and $0.4 million, respectively, was reserved on the Company’s consolidated balance sheets related to uncertain tax positions. 14. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS The Company has evaluated subsequent events through February 26, 2021, the date the consolidated financial statements were available to be issued. On January 5, 2021, the Company published an offer document regarding its previously announced agreement with the board of directors of G4S plc (“G4S”) on a recommended cash offer to acquire the issued and outstanding shares of G4S, an international provider of security services, for 245 pence in cash for each share of G4S, representing a total value of all share capital of G4S of approximately £3.8 billion. The transaction is expected to close in April 2021, subject to the satisfaction (or waiver, if permitted) of certain conditions, including valid acceptance of the transaction by holders of 75% (or such lesser percentage as the Company may decide) of G4S shares, and the completion of certain regulatory approval and clearance processes. On January 16, 2021, the Company completed a purchase of the outstanding equity interests in SecurAmerica, LLC, SecurAmerica Corporation and ERMC LLC (collectively, “SecurAmerica”) for a preliminary purchase price subject to certain post-closing adjustments of approximately $352 million. Based in Atlanta, Georgia, SecurAmerica is a provider of security, asset protection and janitorial services with offices located throughout the United States. In connection with the purchase of SecurAmerica, the Company also deposited $31.5 million into an escrow account to fund the future purchase of substantially all of the assets of SecurAmerica TN LLC and ERMC TN LLC (collectively, “SecurAmerica TN”). Also based in Atlanta, Georgia, SecurAmerica TN is a provider of security and janitorial services. The transaction is expected to close during 2021, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. ----- INDEPENDENT AUDITORS’ REPORT TO THE MEMBERS OF G4S PLC For the year ended 31 December 2020
